review_preview: We saw how busy this one when walking past one night so went online to book, site is in Spanish of course we just guessed everything and it did the job! Booked for 8.30 on a Friday night, place was buzzing when we arrived and...
review_full: We saw how busy this one when walking past one night so went online to book, site is in Spanish of course we just guessed everything and it did the job! Booked for 8.30 on a Friday night, place was buzzing when we arrived and we were taken to the restaurant in the backroom, lovely place candlelit and nice table settings - after eating street food for a couple of days the linen napkins and candles were a nice change! Staff were attentive and very friendly, menus are offered in either Spanish or English. I ordered a glass of house white, beautiful. Bread and chorizo and cheese was brought to the table once we had ordered. We shared potatas bravas for starters - one of the best if not THE best we’ve ever had! The sauce they put on top with the tomato sauce was amazing, still no idea what it was but gorgeous! Partner had the prawn risotto for main, so buttery and tasty and good size, struggled to finish it. I ordered the tuna on pickles with potatoes, tuna was rare and seared on the outside but fell apart, one of the best meals we’ve ever had. Place filled up fast and can see why you need to book. Bar was busy and spilling into the street when left, really good atmosphere and really good staff. Would go again if in Madrid! In our opinion very good value for money considering the standard of the food. Book so you don’t miss out!

title_review: Disappointing meal. Doesn't deserve a Michelin Star. Overcooked food. Bad wine pairings. Inattentive service.
review_preview: Since A'Barra had been awarded a Michelin Star, I had expected the restaurant to provide excellent service, gourmet food, and good-quality wine. My husband and I had dinner at A'Barra, and the meal was very disappointing. My fish appetizer was okay, but the partridge entree...
review_full: Since A'Barra had been awarded a Michelin Star, I had expected the restaurant to provide excellent service, gourmet food, and good-quality wine. My husband and I had dinner at A'Barra, and the meal was very disappointing. My fish appetizer was okay, but the partridge entree was overcooked and dry. My husband also wasn't happy with his food. And the wine pairings chosen by A'Barra weren't good. The wine didn't complement the food, plus the wine was expensive but tasted cheap, lacking the bouquet and flavor you would expect from good wine. The service was uneven. When we first arrived at the restaurant, the server was polite and attentive, but he seemed inexperienced. Later, when the restaurant became more crowded, we were ignored by the servers and even had to ask for our check several times. When we left the restaurant, we were hungry. The only thing good about the restaurant was the decor--lovely stone floors and interesting light fixtures.

title_review: Great food. But a dull place
review_preview: We read some good reviews about this place and decided to try it out, on a Thursday night. Filled to maybe one fourth capacity, there was absolutely nothing to make this place be described as lively. To accompany our rose wine and colonial cocktail that...
review_full: We read some good reviews about this place and decided to try it out, on a Thursday night. Filled to maybe one fourth capacity, there was absolutely nothing to make this place be described as lively. To accompany our rose wine and colonial cocktail that was quite tasty and definitely recommendable, we thoroughly enjoyed the steak tartare, and beef ceviche. Though both these were delicious, the tacos were ok, but nothing to complain about. Had the atmosphere been more lively we would have lingered over more drinks,but the dullness of the ambience that had absolutely nothing to warrant its name of circus, made us leave and seek out another place with better atmosphere.

title_review: PLACE TO GO - HAPPY WITH MY VISIT
review_preview: It is a place with a very sophisticated decoration, in an interesting location to investigate the area and this neighborhood with so much character of Madrid.We went to have a wine with some friends and finally we ended up having some tapas and a...
review_full: It is a place with a very sophisticated decoration, in an interesting location to investigate the area and this neighborhood with so much character of Madrid. We went to have a wine with some friends and finally we ended up having some tapas and a cocktail. I recommend the wine list, with references of different varieties and good mix of diferents regions, we ask for a white wine from Madrid with a variety in danger extinction and that you only find in Madrid and surroundings, was excellent! Then we order oysters, cheese platter, and mussels .. good presentation and great quality, very fresh seafood, small-medium quantities, more to tapas than to dine. We finished with a chocolate cake and a well-made and light coktail. Music was fun and with an indie-cool touch .. but they said during night they have a DJ and is more for dance. Bartenders and service was actually very good, nice, polite and helpful, well done for them, brilliant staff. It was a good experience and I will come back for sure.

review_full: I went there with my parents for dinner. We didn't try the tasting menu as it needs to be ordered by the whole table. Instead we ordered from the a la carte menu. Overall the food was good but not great. My favourite dish is the pressed duck. It was cooked perfectly and the sauce was delicious. However the service desperately needs improvement. Some of the waiters were very inexperienced. One of them tried to slice the duck in front us but almost dropped the duck on the floor! A senior waiter had to take over and asked the young guy to press the bones. But again the poor guy spilled the juice!  My parents didn't feel like drinking so I ordered totally 4 glasses of different wine. The amount the waiters poured in each glass was so little that I thought it was just for tasting. I think generally they didn't pour more than 80cc per glass. I'm sure they can easily pour more than 10 glasses from each bottle.  Overall I think the experience was not worth the one Michelin star.

review_preview: The restaurant has different options to enjoy its food (showcooking, tasting menu or just menu). I should say that the menu (not tasting menu) hasn’t many dishes but I consider they are enough. Our idea was to order tasting menu, but one of us couldn’t...
review_full: The restaurant has different options to enjoy its food (showcooking, tasting menu or just menu). I should say that the menu (not tasting menu) hasn’t many dishes but I consider they are enough. Our idea was to order tasting menu, but one of us couldn’t eat raw food and we decided to choose the menu option. The good point here is that they have the option to order half or complete portion. We choose some dishes included into the tasting menu, considering that these dishes should be a good option… but no. Under my potion of view some dishes needs to be improve it, they didn't bring me something different, and they are a bit expensive (if you considered the "technic"). Attentive service but a little bit disordered, posh atmosphere (maybe for the neighbourhood where the restaurant is). This kind of restaurant needs a second visit to valuate it properly and not take a bad decision, but fortunately Madrid has many restaurant options to choose and to be honest, I am not sure if I want to give them this second round. Good luck!

title_review: Great food, service to be improved
review_preview: Eaten here on a business dinner. Had hamon iberico for starters, which was nothing special honestly. You can get same quality in every supermarket. The cardo soup was very nice though and the pork was truly exceptional.Wine list is also very interesting.What could...
review_full: Eaten here on a business dinner. Had hamon iberico for starters, which was nothing special honestly. You can get same quality in every supermarket. The cardo soup was very nice though and the pork was truly exceptional. Wine list is also very interesting. What could be improved is the service. Quite sloppy (e.g. wine not being presented during tasting, not offering to put coats away, glasses left empty for too long, etc.). All in all, it is a very nice modern restaurant but I would not rate it as a one Michelin star one.

title_review: Amazing team but food is just not good
review_preview: It is a regret to say that the tasting menu is exceptionally poor. They try really hard to fusion some items with Asian but really cannot make it. My thoughts on the food:Bloody mary and anchovy - Hit. Nice refreshing cocktail and very fresh...
review_full: It is a regret to say that the tasting menu is exceptionally poor.  They try really hard to fusion some items with Asian but really cannot make it. My thoughts on the food: Bloody mary and anchovy - Hit. Nice refreshing cocktail and very fresh anchovy. Shrimp fritters - Miss. This is a very easy street snack that’s available in so many Asian countries which requires practically zero effort.  Ham, eggs, potato - Hit. Nice but effortless Shaomai - This was a major turn off. Tastes nth like shaomai, it’s like a tomato broth thing and chickpeas is nothing to do with Asian food so I can’t relate this to shaomai Peppers - Miss. Nothing special honestly, night as well have a plate of padron peppers Rooster wattle - Requested to change and I don’t want to eat weird stuff. Got a fried cod which was a hit - it tastes good, sweet n sourish. Brioche stuffed with tail curry and green shiso - Miss. It’s like a mixture of Indian, trying to add Japanese. Too confusing  Mushroom ramen - Miss. I don’t know what is this dish trying to achieve, it’s neither asian nor western. It’s very very poorly done and bland. Red Prawns - Hit. One of the best dish by far, but it’s just effortless grilled prawns Wild turbot - Miss. Mine was undercooked and my partner one looks burnt Pork - Miss. Covered by unappetising black stuff and the pork is just bland. Like the piece of pork I throw into the Asiansoup for flavouring. It’s really horrible Desserts - Hit. Thank goodness for yummy desserts to makeup for a terrible meal. More misses than hits. However, I have to admit that the bar concept idea is amazing where everyone eats the same time so it’s consistent. Staffs are definitely 5 stars and they go out of the way to make you feel so comfortable dining here. The wine pairing is also amazing despite lousy food.  The team is really amazing but the food really needs to change - it can’t be Asian influences as none of it would pass any Asian tongue. I’m okay as i’m very adventurous but not towards half-half kind of food which is neither here nor there, and most importantly if it does not taste good.  It’s funny to observe the people opposite us who stuffed themselves with bread and gave funny faces. Couple on the left kept complaining. Couple on the right was annoyed too and kept asking us how was the food. Clearly most people in the room did not enjoy their food (the way they complained and their body language too).  Nevertheless, the team should receive a compliment for being amazing people.

review_preview: Our hotel was able to book us a table at the last minute and as it has a one star Michelin,  it raised our expectations a notch.On service ---The team tried hard to please and be attentive. On food-- we ordered the tasting menu....
review_full: Our hotel was able to book us a table at the last minute and as it has a one star Michelin, it raised our expectations a notch. On service ---The team tried hard to please and be attentive.  On food-- we ordered the tasting menu. They asked if we were allergic to any food or anything we did not eat and would adjust the menu accordingly. The cold shrimp soup was extremely salty and to a point where it was bitter. We brought this to the staff's attention, and they replaced it with a cold tomato soup. It was still a bit on the salty side, but better than the cold shrimp soup.  The tuna was not special. For a fine dining restaurant, the dish was not that spectacular. It felt like someone seared a tuna steak. And the presentation of the dish was very simple. Then came the pork. It was very tender and you would not need a knife to cut it. But it looks like a piece of dark colour pork on a plate.  Overall, I was not impressed by this one star michelin restaurant.

There are many wonderful restaurants Michelin starred in Spain - this one definitely does not deserve its one star.

title_review: A stunning place but ... no heart
review_preview: We needed a last-minute reservation and the hotel recommended this newly-starred restaurant...the sister restaurant of a starred one that was full.  It was designed for flash and had a chef's table premise.  We sat is the normal dining room, so the review is based on...
review_full: We needed a last-minute reservation and the hotel recommended this newly-starred restaurant...the sister restaurant of a starred one that was full. It was designed for flash and had a chef's table premise. We sat is the normal dining room, so the review is based on that "half". The staff were aiming for that tricky combo -- polished (lifting of the plate covers in unison) but casual (jeans and sneakers) and missed. Our main young woman was just not trained/knowledgeable. The tables were spaced and you could talk. They had a "great sourcing" premise, but frankly, most of the food in good Madrid restaurants can do this, and the "compensation" in décor and service couldn't quite pull it off. The food was generally delicious and well-prepared (desserts were remarkable) and you will be happy here, but...see my review of Lua for a compare.

It is 14 courses for dinner. The bar was not busy at lunch. The tasting menu was 50€ per person. The chef was with us every step of the way. We enjoyed watching the chef and other cooks work. The detailed explanations before each course were terrific and we enjoyed chatting with the chef. The courses ranged in size from small to medium, which allowed us to eat everything. The presentation was lovely. Flavors were lively and interesting. Our favorites were the tomato/olive bonbon, the beet vinaigrette on the salad and the interesting cod "churro". We had nice wine to complement the meal. We will return.

review_preview: A'barra was the first dinner of my three night indulgence (A'barra, Cebo and Ramon Freixa, see all reviews) in Madrid. Each dinner was exceptional in its own way, elegant, beautifully presented and delicious, creative food. Each small bite or dish was exquisite, each meal was...
review_full: A'barra was the first dinner of my three night indulgence (A'barra, Cebo and Ramon Freixa, see all reviews) in Madrid. Each dinner was exceptional in its own way, elegant, beautifully presented and delicious, creative food. Each small bite or dish was exquisite, each meal was substantial and I loved the creativity of each of these chefs. The service at each location was superb, the staff were extremely educated on the dishes and eager to share their knowledge, and extremely attentive to your needs and desires. You left each location feeling pampered. Each location was a special, elegant restaurant where you did not feel out of place in jeans and a nice shirt. Each was artfully decorated, and beautiful in its own right. Note: These dinners allow the chefs to be creative in their art, this is not the place you come to for standard fare. Enjoying this meal includes opening you mind and palate to the possibilities and creativity of each of these artists.  Dinner at each of these restaurants is a decadent treat and I was privileged to be able to do three of these on consecutive nights. Specific to A'barra. Food: The food was excellent. It was on the modern side, but I loved the flashbacks to traditional flavors. The meal was hearty and on the richer side. I loved the variety of flavors and the presentation was beautiful.  This is not a restaurant fir vegetarians. My wife was disappointed with her dinner and expected more from a chef of this caliber.  Ambiance: This was the most elaborately decorated of the three restaurants. It had a more formal atmosphere and feel to the restaurant. The tables, chairs and fixtures were exquisite. The atmosphere ensured that you were going to be spoilt. Service: Once again fabulous service, attentive and caring.  We loved dinner here, except for my wife, and would recommend this restaurant.

title_review: My favourite restaurant in Madrid (and I live here for 6 years now)
review_preview: Casa Macareno is located in a renovated typical taverna in Madrid. The first you notice coming in is that there was a very strong effort in preserving the original traditional look but adding very cool "twists" to it. The same applies to the food and...
review_full: Casa Macareno is located in a renovated typical taverna in Madrid. The first you notice coming in is that there was a very strong effort in preserving the original traditional look but adding very cool "twists" to it. The same applies to the food and that's one of the reasons why this place is my favourite restaurant in Madrid. My favourite dishes are the "croquetas de jamón" - absolutely delicious (and I've tried my share of them in other places), the seafood fake risotto, the octopus (pulpo), the stuffed squids (chipirones), the pork sirloin (secreto de cerdo), and last but not least the wonderful "milhojas", a mille-feuille - a dessert made with stacked layers of puff pastry filled with dulce de leche: a creamy mix of condensed milk, sugar, and vanilla. The service is very friendly, easy-going, relaxed yet professional, exactly the way I like it. Overall: I'm afraid you haven't been to Madrid if you didn't eat here.

Like he had said, this is more Spanish and definitely one for the locals but one that us tourist folk will love. It was mid afternoon, hot and we had been wandering lots.  Perfect time for tapas and a refreshment ;) Again the staff here are great, explained all the tapas options while we ordered drinks and there choices did not disappoint. Unfortunately I cannot remember the ages but the pics show how good it was. Like the restaurant from previous nights. The flavours where fab, all so fresh and a perfect size, enough to keep you satisfied without spooling appetite for that nights meal. A chef came out to chat and checked all was okay and told us a bit about the bar and that nights menu.  It's a place to stop for an espresso, a beer or a full sit down food adventure. As I'm saying with most off my Madrid trip reviews. It's a definite must check out if your in the city and love great food matched to great service and atmosphere. Enjoy Mike & Emma

review_preview: First the good, the space is truly beautiful, the service is wonderful, very well orchestrated, if a bit over the top.  Amazing wine list, great sommelier.  The strange thing about this place is that while it tries to portray a progressive, modern, relaxed decor, the...
review_full: First the good, the space is truly beautiful, the service is wonderful, very well orchestrated, if a bit over the top. Amazing wine list, great sommelier. The strange thing about this place is that while it tries to portray a progressive, modern, relaxed decor, the service is very old-school formal, bordering on stuffy. The uniforms, for example, look like something out of a Nantucket beach resort, khakis, sperry top siders, bow ties, but they move and act as if wearing tails. Oddly, our waiter's pants had two holes on his behind apparently caused by the wallet. This alone makes it bizarre. Very high end, all attention to details, but they don't give the waiter a new pair of pants so he parades around with holes on his rear end. Now the food. After all, while decor goes a long way, what good is it without great food. I had the vegetable appetizer, it was bland and way overcooked, honestly tasted like it came from the frozen section of the supermarket. The seabass, bland, very bland, and while it was a generous portion, the center was so undercooked it was spongy and chewy, therefore unedible. The chef can't figure out how to cook seabass? My friend ordered the beef and that was way better, I should have followed suit. Bottom line? I will not return. Shame, for the space is truly beautiful and the service just needs a new pair of pants, but the food is disappointing.

title_review: Outstanding food, wine, and service--deserves the Michelin star!
review_preview: We had a big family lunch at A Barra in a residential area of Madrid.  This is a one-star Michelin restaurant and definitely deserves the star, food-wise, service-wise, and price-wise.  It's a fairly new restaurant and will probably earn another star at some point in...
review_full: We had a big family lunch at A Barra in a residential area of Madrid. This is a one-star Michelin restaurant and definitely deserves the star, food-wise, service-wise, and price-wise. It's a fairly new restaurant and will probably earn another star at some point in the near future. Among the nine of us, we shared many small plates of outstandingly presented and delicious food--very high-end imaginative dishes and excellent service. The folks who work there are true professionals. What was really cool was that each time a new plate was presented (each person had a portion placed at his seating), all of the plates were covered with a dome, and each person had a server, and they all lifted the domes at one time--extraordinary!  After we dined, we were given a tour of the restaurant, which was very impressive. They even have a "mesa zero"--table number zero, which is located in the kitchen, where the diners can watch everything being prepared and have interactions with the chef. A definite come-back-to on our next trip to Madrid.

title_review: Excelent and modern, but not crazy modern.
review_preview: I don't see her all that often due to the ocean that separates us, so when we are in the same city I like taking my Grandmother out to restaurants where the food will be at least as great as the company.So this choice...
review_full: I don't see her all that often due to the ocean that separates us, so when we are in the same city I like taking my Grandmother out to restaurants where the food will be at least as great as the company. So this choice was made bearing in mind that the food was guaranteed to be delicious, the service courteous, and the dishes modern but not puzzlingly modern. My Grandmother likes to recognise the ingredients in her dish, so a place that serves "deconstructed Spanish tortilla foam" was out of the question. A'Barra was a great choice. We ate a la carte (I tend to like long tasting menus but my Grandmother isn't such a fan of them), and I had to say it was difficult to pick... it all sounded fantastic. Their food is indeed spectacularly flavourful, good combinations without being exceedingly complex dishes, representing northern-Spain dishes. Service was always very polite and professional. We all enjoyed it fully and would strongly recommend it.

title_review: Fantastic food, superb service, amazing value
review_preview: There are many places to eat in Madrid, this is genuinely one of the best. The signature dish of Asturian cachopo (breaded steak with melted cheese and ham) is delicious and reasonably priced at €16 for enough to feed three people. It's a heart attack...
review_full: There are many places to eat in Madrid, this is genuinely one of the best. The signature dish of Asturian cachopo (breaded steak with melted cheese and ham) is delicious and reasonably priced at €16 for enough to feed three people. It's a heart attack on a plate, but what a way to go. The grilled octopus is similarly an absolute bargain for the quality. When you ask for the wine list the waitress says "I'll fetch him!". Her husband, the owner is knowledgable, attentive and passionate about their food and wine. They make a great team, and El Cogollo makes for a great dining experience.

Typical Spanish fare yet prepared with the freshest ingredients and always with a little twist. The patatas bravas were out of this world. I have never tasted anything so delicious in my life, and I have had my share of bravas. The pork was cooked to perfection, the wines, affordable and delicious. Prices were extremely reasonable, service was perfection, and it is definitely the local address where you want too eat, drink and absorb local culture with friends. I could not recommend more highly.

While we were eating and drinking, the table of what appeared to be locals sitting behind us brought out guitars and began playing and singing in traditional Spanish style. We were thrilled to be entertained by the impromptu performance and were satisfied by the tapas for the price of the drinks. This type of experience is exactly what we hope for in our travels!

title_review: My new favorite restaurant in Madrid!  Service and food excellent.  Look no further.
review_preview: We were blown away by the service and food at O’Pulpo.  My partner lives in Madrid and can’t believe we didn’t come across this place earlier.  It is on a quiet street off the beaten track and a 10min walk from Plaza Major.  It has...
review_full: We were blown away by the service and food at O’Pulpo. My partner lives in Madrid and can’t believe we didn’t come across this place earlier. It is on a quiet street off the beaten track and a 10min walk from Plaza Major. It has few tables so book especially on the weekend. We had super fresh and tasty razor clams, octopus that melted in your mouth (the potatoes were divine), tomato and tuna salad and an amazing and huge grilled sole cooked perfectly and so big we couldn’t finish it. House white wine, dessert (ice cream was so so, only thing to improve) coffee and a free orujo we spent 85eur in two for a super tasty and fresh meal. The waiter was incredibly professional and nice. We are definitely going back! Side note: there were tons of people at the bar too so I suppose the tapas bar and the “menu del dia” (fixed lunch menu at 15eur) is excellent as well.

title_review: Superb food in the heart of Madrid at a reasonable price
review_preview: Just a few metres from the tourist-trap that is the Plaza Mayor you will find this wonderful local restaurant without tourists and without high prices. The owner, Miguel, is from the northern Spanish province of Asturias but has lived in Madrid for over 30 years....
review_full: Just a few metres from the tourist-trap that is the Plaza Mayor you will find this wonderful local restaurant without tourists and without high prices. The owner, Miguel, is from the northern Spanish province of Asturias but has lived in Madrid for over 30 years. The food is typical Asturiana featuring fresh sea bass, hake, as well as lamb, kid goat, beef. I had a terrific white-fish salad to start followed by grilled octopus on a bed of potatoes. The restaurant has a good selection of wines and beers but as this was an Asturian restaurant, I opted for a bottle of cider, my wife a couple of glasses of white wine. Coffee and liquors. My wife and I ate and drank too much and left with a bill of just over 50 euros. For the centre of Madrid that is a bargain. Take the 1 minute walk from the Plaza Mayor and try this place. You won't regret it.

title_review: If you are in Madrid, book a table here, seriously!
review_preview: I ate here in June 2014 and was impressed. One year later and nothing has changed. I booked a table a week in advance (phone only in Spanish) for 15:30 but have your hotel do it for you if you don't speak Castellano. (Weekdays best...
review_full: I ate here in June 2014 and was impressed. One year later and nothing has changed. I booked a table a week in advance (phone only in Spanish) for 15:30 but have your hotel do it for you if you don't speak Castellano. (Weekdays best to do it at least 48hrs before) My wife had grilled "pulpo" (octopus) while I had their award-winning "cachopo" (thin cut sirloin steak with sliced jamón serrano and cheese in a delicate batter, deep fried. Typical regional dish from the northern province of Asturias. Wonderful. Not the dish for a diet, nor for one person. Two could easily have this as a main course and at only 17 euros a true bargain. Last year El Cogollo won first prize for the best "cachopo" in Madrid. I had two bottles of Asturian cider, my wife two or three glasses of a decent Albariño white wine from Galicia. Four coffees, one dessert. I think we paid 52 euros. Miguel, the owner who is from Asturias but has lived in Madrid for over thirty years gave me a couple of free "chupitos" of "orujo con miel" (Asturian Marc/brandy with honey). I have been drinking this for years. It is delicious and hard to find outside of Asturias. This place is always full of "madrileños (Madrid natives) so please book a table if you don't want to be turned away. For price/quality you will be hard pressed to find a more authentic local restaurant in the centre of Madrid. Don't worry if you don't speak Spanish. Both Android and I-phones have good translation apps. If you aren't tech savy just point at the food you see at other tables.

title_review: I am so glad we ate here!
review_preview: Since we were staying in La Latina neighborhood, we wanted to check out some nice place to eat dinner on our last night before heading back home. I pulled the Tripadvisor App to check out nearby places, and El Cogollo showed up along with several...
review_full: Since we were staying in La Latina neighborhood, we wanted to check out some nice place to eat dinner on our last night before heading back home. I pulled the Tripadvisor App to check out nearby places, and El Cogollo showed up along with several restaurants. We decided to give it a try.  La Latina is a neighborhood that has a lot of activity at night, there are tons of restaurants and tabernas with people sitting outside.  We were very skeptical when we arrived at El Cogollo. There were no tables outside, it looked isolated from the rest.  When we entered, we noticed everything was full and the server asked us if we wanted to wait. We decided to do so.  Long story short, this place is amazing.. the service is outstanding! The server made sure all of her tables were taken care of! And she was the only one for a full restaurant, you can see she was working really hard.  We had the gambas al ajillo (shrimp with garlic) OUTSTANDING! And of course the Cachopo, which we noticed everyone was having.  We learned about Asturian food and we absolutely loved it! Definitely recommended to go with your spouse or partner or with friends!

title_review: Fabulous traditional Spanish food, served by passionate and knowledgable staff
review_preview: We found Casa Macareno by chance  but couldn't get a table for a few nights as we had to book. It was worth the wait. This was by far the best meal we had in Madrid during the week of our stay and the family...
review_full: We found Casa Macareno by chance but couldn't get a table for a few nights as we had to book. It was worth the wait. This was by far the best meal we had in Madrid during the week of our stay and the family all reckon it was one of the best meals we've eaten anywhere in a long time. Rarely have we met staff/owners who were so passionate and knowledgeable about the food they produce. Our choices from the menu were largely guided by the staff and they served up the courses in tapas style so that we all got to taste a variety of dishes for each course. Strongly recommend anyone to check this gem out but (unsurprisingly) you will need to book.

I've been here several times, and the experience is always the same, outstanding. That is the signature of a restaurant that cares about its patrons.

review_full: We received a recommendation from local store owners to try this place. It was a 5 star  recommendation to a 5 Star time. First, the location is near the Plaza Mayor, but is tucked out of the way. The restaurant is small, about 8 tables. Dinner begins at 8:30 and if you are timely, seating should be ok. By 9:30, it is full. The food is terrific and plentiful. It is Comida Asturiana fare from northern Spain. My wife and I shared a very tasty salad of lettuce, tuna and tomato sauce. I assure you, the dish tasted way better than I am making it sound. I wish we could find something like this in the U.S. Then we had Cachopo, a dish of veal fillets stuffed with ham and cheese. Again, this description does not do the dish justice. We had been advised in our recommendation that we should share the dish and our waitress affirmed that. A total understatement. My wife and I shared half of the portion presented and we took the other half home for tomorrow. And it was terrific. While fairly full, we simply had to try and share a dessert. We ordered a torte de Lupe. OMG!! Awesome. And fairly light. Finally, the house wines were very good, and so was the bread. The atmosphere was really nice, dark blue table cloths with a white top cloth, if that helps set the scene. Service was perfect and friendly. This all earns El Cogollo the 5 stars. But know that the "cuenta" came to 42 Euros, before tip. Incredible. We have been in Spain now 28 days. We have eaten at different restaurants for all but 3 days. Some at very high end places with bill's the were 3 times tonight's. But NONE were better. Treat yourself.

title_review: Excellent place to taste famous Cachopo!
review_preview: Since we heard about Cachopo in TV Show Masterchef, we have been trying to taste this Asturian dish. When we decided to visit Madrid, I started looking for places where Cachopo was offered in the menu. There are at least 4 places, but this one...
review_full: Since we heard about Cachopo in TV Show Masterchef, we have been trying to taste this Asturian dish. When we decided to visit Madrid, I started looking for places where Cachopo was offered in the menu. There are at least 4 places, but this one seems to be the best from a quality-price point of view. Is located close to Plaza Mayor and I strongly recommend to book in advance. The place is relatively small. We order 1 goat cheese salad and 1 traditional cachopo. It was enough for 2 adults. Enjoy as much as you can while eating your cachopo. Is recommended always to share the cachopo, but is your choice if you want to eat it alone! I recommend this place and hopefully will repeat a visit!

review_preview: A "cachopo" is a popular dish from a northern region of Spain called "Asturias" which combines three kinds of delicious meats with a heart of melted cheeses and a thick breaded cove. Only for starving carnivorous!At 'El Cogollo de la Descarga" you will find...

Only for starving carnivorous! At 'El Cogollo de la Descarga" you will find also another typical dishes like chorizos, octopus, croquetas, cabrales-style potatoes... I went there because it's one of my best friends favourite places in Madrid and I know now why... If you have the chance, don't miss it! When we left the restaurant (5 p.m.) it was still full of people having lunch, so it's a convenient place to go if you want to find a good restaurant to have lunch at that hour...

review_preview: The octopus (pulpo a la brasa) is the best I've ever tasted! The perfect combination of almost crisp exterior, and the tender flesh (reminded me of lobster texture) and garlic oil was delicious. I'm still thinking about it a day later and hoping for the...
review_full: The octopus (pulpo a la brasa) is the best I've ever tasted! The perfect combination of almost crisp exterior, and the tender flesh (reminded me of lobster texture) and garlic oil was delicious. I'm still thinking about it a day later and hoping for the next day to return and eat this again. We also had the cachopo, which is thin/flattened steak stuffed with ham and cheese, breaded and fried - a bit like a cross between a chicken cordon bleu and an American chicken-fried steak. This was also good, and the portion was huge, but to me it wasn't as special as the octopus. If you had to choose between the two, I'd definitely recommend the octopus. Value was great - €18 for the pulpo and €16 for the cachopo, considering the portion size. Ambience was decent, as a local restaurant, and round the corner from the Mercado de San Miguel and near Plaza Mayor. Wait staff I think don't speak much English, but they are friendly enough. Besides, you only need to order the pulpo or cachopo and some vino or cerveca anyway so no need to bother much with the menu ;-) If you are around the area and want an authentic local place (I think we were the only non Spanish in the place), then I can heartily recommend it.

Off the beaten track but close enough/far enough from the touristy restaurants to have a very, very nice meal.

title_review: Wonderful experience of local dining in Madrid!
review_preview: We loved our experience at El Cogollo for dinner in Madrid.  Although the staff did not speak much English, other diners were eager to help.  We had a wonderful dish of octopus, another in our party had Shrimp, also delicious.  Another had a specialty from...
review_full: We loved our experience at El Cogollo for dinner in Madrid. Although the staff did not speak much English, other diners were eager to help. We had a wonderful dish of octopus, another in our party had Shrimp, also delicious. Another had a specialty from the northern Basque Country which was a fried beef stuffed with cheese. This felt like a very local restaurant. Not touristy at all and the prices were very reasonable. Excellent choice if you want an authentic Spanish dining experience.

review_full: We stopped in because of the great reviews and we were in the mood for empanadas and a glass of wine. We checked the menu outside and we're sure we made the right call until we got inside and saw another couple sharing a pizza. It looked so good that we ended up getting one. We come from the land of great pizza, so I never expected to have one of the top 5 pizzas ever in a small little tapas place in Madrid. We got the standard Margherita pizza with fresh tomatoes and basil, but it was the homemade dough and the oregano infused sauce that really made it great. The sauce was also perfectly caramelized on the crust. If the same excellence and care go into the empanadas I'm sure they're great too.

title_review: Quaint little tapas/ wine place with great homemade empanadas and
review_preview: Went to this quiet, hidden little gem twice while in Madrid because its homemade food was so exquisite.  Try the empanadas of the day, the homemade quiche, or one of their "toastas"-- which are large pieces of toasted French bread with delicious toppings (I loved...
review_full: Went to this quiet, hidden little gem twice while in Madrid because its homemade food was so exquisite. Try the empanadas of the day, the homemade quiche, or one of their "toastas"-- which are large pieces of toasted French bread with delicious toppings (I loved the one with goat cheese medallions covered with carmelized onions on top of a fresh tomato spread). Good list of wines too. Good coffee, desserts and other drinks. And very inexpensive: cost only about 18 Euros for two lunches. Most of the people there were young locals, which should tell you a lot.

title_review: Good food at a good price point for the area.
review_preview: We booked this restaurant on-line for a Thursday evening dinner after seeing a number of groups of folks entering and exiting what appeared to be a packed restaurant on the previous Sunday afternoon as we walked this lovely area of Madrid.  On our arrival at...
review_full: We booked this restaurant on-line for a Thursday evening dinner after seeing a number of groups of folks entering and exiting what appeared to be a packed restaurant on the previous Sunday afternoon as we walked this lovely area of Madrid. On our arrival at just after 9pm, much to our surprise, the restaurant was literally empty and the waiter seemed surprised to see us or anyone for that matter. He said they had no reservations on the system. After some back and forth in broken Spanish (no one spoke English there but we and they were patient in our exchange). They found the reservation and we were seated. After this unsettling start, I can say that we were treated warmly and had a lovely meal feeling moe comfortable though a bit lonely :-). They have a menu of the day that is very affordable and with a nice selection of appetizers and main dishes as well as ala carte with all the items leaning on classic Spanish dishes which was a major reason we chose this spot. Our meals were quite good. Wine selection was also very good. We learned that the restaurant is usually packed for lunch and often very quiet for dinner. Only 3 other couples were dining on our departure at 11 and enjoying the food as well.

title_review: Best vegan meal in continental Europe
review_preview: This is fantastic. Especially the tapas (which are huge, you don’t need to order loads). I’ve been to many many vegan restaurants in France, Spain, etc, and often find myself having a burger and chips. This is healthy, creative, and plays on the best of...
review_full: This is fantastic. Especially the tapas (which are huge, you don’t need to order loads). I’ve been to many many vegan restaurants in France, Spain, etc, and often find myself having a burger and chips. This is healthy, creative, and plays on the best of Spanish cuisine. I brought my best friend from Liverpool who said “I’ve never considered a vegan restaurant and wouldn’t never normally go” and he ended up loving it and finishing every dish. Well worth a trip in Madrid.

A bit obscure locale, near the Prado Museum, worth seeking out.

review_preview: Before we got lucky and stumbled upon Tinto y Tapas, my husband and I had searched in vain for a tapas bar with at least a few menu items that weren't all about ham and/or cheese. (We like to indulge as much as the next...

(We like to indulge as much as the next guy, but...jeez...we could feel our arteries closing up after our first 4-5 days in the ham heaven that is Spain! And let's not get started on the whole manchego-mania...)  Chef Diego, a wonderful, joyful gentleman, knows how to make his guests feel welcome -- and, yes, how to offer them tempting menu items that aren't ALL heavy and cholesterol-laden. Thanks, Chef, for lots of luscious smoked salmon (and a few other things). We -- Karen and Gerardo -- will never forget your cozy tapas bar and your warm, welcoming manner. Muchas gracias!

Highly recomendable.

title_review: Excellent home style cooking at a very reasonable price
review_preview: The "menu del dia" is exceptional and cheap. Market cooking, simple and tasty. Try salmorejo. It is probably one of the best in Spain (yes that includes Cordoba). The migas (bread with different pork portions, including chorizo, morcilla, panceta) are good to excellent. Cocido (usually...
review_full: The "menu del dia" is exceptional and cheap. Market cooking, simple and tasty. Try salmorejo. It is probably one of the best in Spain (yes that includes Cordoba). The migas (bread with different pork portions, including chorizo, morcilla, panceta) are good to excellent. Cocido (usually on Thursdays) is also very good . Even the menu wine is good (from Utiel). If you wish to try the "a la carte" the cooking is high level inside the simplicity. Fresh ingredients and simple recepies. Very tasty. The quality : price ratio is outstanding. Just be aware of making a reservation if you go for lunch daily or anytime during the weekends.

title_review: Great tavern for a great price.
review_preview: We used to come to this bar quite often while i lived in Madrid. The bar has two sections, one as restaurant and one as standing bar. The restaurant has a quite good selection of dishes from Galicia with good prices. However, we usually went...
review_full: We used to come to this bar quite often while i lived in Madrid. The bar has two sections, one as restaurant and one as standing bar. The restaurant has a quite good selection of dishes from Galicia with good prices. However, we usually went to the other section. If you don't mind to stay standing in a crowded place surrounded by groups of locals catching up this is the place. With every drink you order they provide something to eat which is often not big but after 4-5 cañas (small size beer) added up to be a dinner. We used to close the night with a bottle of Ribeiro (white wine from Galicia). The bill was always dirt cheap, all the friends visiting I took there loved the place.

title_review: Amazing authentic atmosphere, drinks and tapas!
review_preview: We visited this restaurant on a Saturday night during our trip to Madrid, and walking in at first sight the place was packed and had a very local vibe inside. We sat at the bar for wine and cervecas and were given the most delicious...
review_full: We visited this restaurant on a Saturday night during our trip to Madrid, and walking in at first sight the place was packed and had a very local vibe inside. We sat at the bar for wine and cervecas and were given the most delicious and generous tapas compared to any other bar. Each round was different and the bar tenders were extremely understanding and patient with our broken Spanish. They picked up on the fact that my girlfriend didn't eat meat (just fish) even though we didn't say anything, and made a special effort to serve her only vegetarian or fish. We ended up spending about 20 euro and left so full, drunk and happy! Going back to Madrid this will be our very first stop! Highly reccomend this place to anyone who wants to get out of the tourist neighboorhood and get a taste of what a real local and authentic vibe feels like. Fantastic service overall!

title_review: A Great Experience for Our First Night in Madrid
review_preview: This restaurant is located in one of the loveliest neighborhoods - right near Retiro Park on a quiet street.  You could easily walk by and miss it - but don't!  It is worth the experience.  We arrived on the early side for Spain (about 8:00...
review_full: This restaurant is located in one of the loveliest neighborhoods - right near Retiro Park on a quiet street. You could easily walk by and miss it - but don't! It is worth the experience. We arrived on the early side for Spain (about 8:00 p.m.) and enjoyed a delicious appetizer of fresh, thinly sliced jamon iberico (right off the leg - a technique that is interesting to watch). My husband and I enjoyed two exquisite meals. The fish was simply prepared and served with a choice of sauces - I chose a tomato, and my husband chose something more like a lemon butter. Both were delicious as was the dessert. This is a small, cozy restaurant - good for a romantic evening. A worthwhile treat!

review_full: This might be the longest review i have ever written, and usually that would he a bad thing bc there are always lots of things to complain about, but we loved this place SO much that i had so much to write about!  Im just a regular joe, not a snooty food connoisseur, so take what I say with a grain of salt, I guess. We found this place, kinda by accident. We were vacationing here from the states, on our way to the ATM to get some euros and passed by this place, which looked cool but a little intimidating. It was a packed bar area with what seemed like a lot of locals, and we dont really (not really at all) speak spanish so we were a bit weary. But, as soon as you walk in, the guys at the bar are shouting asking you what you want to drink, even though we are 2-3 people back from the bar, just inside the door. Hmmm, not sure but let’s go with some beer. They pour it right up and we pick it up at the bar. So far so good. Then they send out a tapa. Um, we didnt order this but they insisted that it was for us. Ok, sure. Some sort of fried eggplant. Im not an eggplant person, but it was good. Then they bring us a menu, in spanish, until they realize we dont speak spanish, so they bring us an English menu, very nice service. Prices seem super reasonable, 2.50 euro beer, 2 euro red wine, assorted tapas from like 2-12 euros. We are not really sure what to get food wise, so we order 2 red wines. Taste fine, but another tapa comes out. Again, excuse, we didnt order, still for us. Ok, thanks.  That was pretty much how the night went. We would order drinks, they would send out tapas. We would order more drinks, they would bring out more tapas. Cant remember all the tapas we had but the fried calamari was unreal, like melt in your mouth. The knives clams were good. Everything was really tasty. The guys next to us got this steak, looked delicious.  So, end of the night, we ask for the bill and we are alittle worried since we werent really specifying which wine or beer when we ordered, and we had gotten a bunch of tapas that we had not ordered. BUT, when we got the bill, we had to do a few double takes. There were just some charges for some beers and wines (2.5 euros for beer, 2 euros for wine) and no charges for food. Had to confirm with the servers and they said everything was right.  So it was such a great night, with great drinks, great food, great service and great atmosphere, we had to go back the next night. We ordered more items off the menu (had to try the steak!) and it was amazing again! Only problem is we had to leave the next day for Cordoba and Seville! Until we are back in Madrid, we will be counting the days to come back!  Go early and find a good spot at the bar or along the windows. The place fills up quick! But everyone inside is super nice so it doesnt “feel” crowded. ENJOY!

I chose the large fillet sirloin equivalent oddered rare. It was amazing and melt in the mouth experience. The chorizo starter showed how great proper chorizo is, not the bullet like ones I have back home. I will be back..

review_full: The staff is very nice. The menu offers different typically Italian dishes, where pasta is the main product. It also has a selection of fine Italian wines. Lovely decoration and tones are neutral but intimate. Dishes on the menu: I liked the salad with bogavante/lobster (although a small portion) was very good. The Vitello tonné was excellent but my spinach and ricotta ravioli with Lemmon sauce and red pepper weren’t up to the concept: raviolis were too cooked and the Lemmon sauce didn’t taste very much. My friends took the pasta with Tartuffo which is pasta fresca with peeled truffle, and an egg yolk to mix as soon as it arrives on the table. The said that they liked it. Didn’t try. And at last but not least the Pannacotta with mango sauce and seeds, which was excellent. Not still a four star but it is slowly arriving. Wine for me was a very good Nero d’Avola. Will I repeat the experience? Perhaps, to see if my pasta is not overcooked.

review_preview: What a great find! This is a perfect option if you crave Italian food while in Madrid. The restaurant is nicely decorated and the staff is very friendly.The food was wonderful. For starters we had a perfect Vitello Tonnato (thin slices of veal, with...
review_full: What a great find! This is a perfect option if you crave Italian food while in Madrid. The restaurant is nicely decorated and the staff is very friendly. The food was wonderful. For starters we had a perfect Vitello Tonnato (thin slices of veal, with a cream of tuna, anchovies and capers), and a beautiful Insalata di Asparagi e Gamberi Rossi (a salad with asparagus, shrimp, quail eggs and aioli with squid ink). Our main courses were two typical Italian dishes: La Nostra Carbonara (spaghetti with guanciale, Pecorino cheese and slow cooked egg), and Tagliatelle alla Bolognese. Both are very simple dishes that you can find anywhere, but these were really spectacular in their simplicity. At Gioia they really elevated the flavors of these two classics, we loved our food!!! For dessert we had a Gioia di Cioccolato with vanilla ice cream. The chocolate was little too dark for my taste, but it was still good. We will definitely go back!

review_preview: I needed a restaurant in Madrid suitable for a dinner party of 12 for a birthday celebration - one of the party is a vegetarian so I asked the TripAdvisor forum for their recommendation, as looking randomly on the web was proving frustrating.  Villoldo was...
review_full: I needed a restaurant in Madrid suitable for a dinner party of 12 for a birthday celebration - one of the party is a vegetarian so I asked the TripAdvisor forum for their recommendation, as looking randomly on the web was proving frustrating. Villoldo was recommended. I was able to email the restaurant beforehand to check that they could both feed a vegetarian and they could fit us in. They confirmed both. On the evening it was a delight to enter the lovely (slightly out of town) restaurant as they had created a secluded private dining area for my party, which meant we could relax without disturbing other diners. Perfect so far. Then came the menu - great for the meat eaters but not so great for the vegetarian, as once we were there the restaurant waiters seemed to struggle with the concept (despite their prior knowledge and acceptance of the booking) BUT they did rise to the occasion and provided a vegetarian starter and main course. We did struggle a bit with communication (we didn't have much Spanish \ they didn't have much English and there seemed to be only one menu with an English translation but again, that added to the enjoyment of the evening as both sides tried their best. The meat dishes (especially the pork and the lamb) went down very well - a couple of diners even said they were exceptional. It was a lovely evening, the ambience was great and the food overall was very good.

review_preview: We ate at this Parilla (Argentine-style grilled meats)  twice in Madrid.  It was convenient to our hotel, the food was better than average, the atmosphere very nice and the prices were reasonable. The grilled lemon chicken was excellent and worth particular mention.  The wine list...
review_full: We ate at this Parilla (Argentine-style grilled meats) twice in Madrid. It was convenient to our hotel, the food was better than average, the atmosphere very nice and the prices were reasonable. The grilled lemon chicken was excellent and worth particular mention. The wine list is reasonable (for Madrid), as well. One nice touch was that we got several "freebies" that added to the experience, both nights. We got the usual "pre-appetizer", but at the end of the meal, we got a dessert and an unidentified liqueur "on the house". They were unusual and nice.  As you know, in Madrid they eat dinner quite late by our standards, so when we showed up at 8PM, it was just about all foreigners and tourists. I'm quite sure the Spanish flock there later. Be aware that they charge a surcharge (10%) to eat at the sidewalk tables. We got the same effect (and better) by asking for a window table, inside, where we got both some air conditioning AND the street view, which was nice. (Preciados is a pedestrian-only street.)  While I would definitely recommend the restaurant, I thought the service was half-hearted. There was an English menu, so no real problem for a non-Spanish speaker, but the wait staff had virtually no English and I felt service was half-hearted and we were treated as a bit of a "necessary evil". I didn't experience this anywhere else in Spain and am very comfortable cross-culturally, even when not speaking the language so I don't think it was us. It may have just been a lack of staff supervision those two nights. So, bottom line, it's definitely worth a visit, particularly if you're in the mood for a really good piece of grilled chicken or steak. Just be prepared for a possible annoyance and go with the flow.

review_preview: On our last night in Madrid we were looking for somewhere near our hotel (Liabeny) and chose El Gaucho because it looked like something different from other restaurants  and tapas bars we had been to. We were shown to a table down near the back...
review_full: On our last night in Madrid we were looking for somewhere near our hotel (Liabeny) and chose El Gaucho because it looked like something different from other restaurants and tapas bars we had been to. We were shown to a table down near the back of the restaurant and the evening of excellence began. The complimentary sparkling wine and gazpacho and the amazing friendly and efficient staff got us off to the perfect start. We all had steaks and each was served exactly as we requested, were beautifully-presented, and tasted fantastic. Too full for desserts we were nevertheless delighted with the (again complimentary) sorbets and Digestifs. Thanks El Gaucho for making our last night in Spain so memorable.

review_preview: Don’t be fooled by the outside look of the restaurant as at the rear lies a little gem. Very polite staff, speaking a good level of English. Very reasonable priced food and drinks. We were given a glass of rose cava as we sat. You...
review_full: Don’t be fooled by the outside look of the restaurant as at the rear lies a little gem. Very polite staff, speaking a good level of English. Very reasonable priced food and drinks. We were given a glass of rose cava as we sat. You are then given a bread basket with rolls and bread sticks,but beware this is on the menu as a chargeable item including service, added to your bill. We were also given little shot glasses of soup and some small pieces of toast. The steak were lovely and a great salad and portion of chips between us 2 was plenty to eat. On declining deserts, we were presented with a small mango desert and lemon ice, on the house, plus then to our surprise, a glass jar( nearly half a pint in size) full of Madrid’s version of Baileys and 2 shot glasses, again gratis. What a lovely touch and what a lot of freebies. The Baileys had a hint of liquorice and very tasty. I would highly recommend this restaurant for a great steak meal.

review_preview: This place came up in a search for restaurants near Sol, where I was at the time. I always like Argentinian food, and really loved El Gaucho! I had their bar menu deal (menu en barra), where for 13.50 Euro you get a choice of...
review_full: This place came up in a search for restaurants near Sol, where I was at the time. I always like Argentinian food, and really loved El Gaucho!  I had their bar menu deal (menu en barra), where for 13.50 Euro you get a choice of appetizer, a main course, a drink, and coffe or dessert. I had a tasty chorizo (sausage) to start (they also gave me 2 huge slices of awesome, fresh bread, with oil and spices to dip it in), then I had a 200 gram (about 8 oz) of a delicious skirt steak with great fries.  After that, I passed on the dessert! It was so good, and filling. Relly good quality stuff, fresh, and well made! A very pleasant experience, and of course a service with a smile, and a relaxed atmosphere (even though a lot of people were waiting to be seated) completed the picture.

review_preview: We happened across this small restaurant on a visit to Madrid and enjoyed an excellent menu del dia lunch - extremely good value for €10.99 per head which included 3 courses, a drink (a glass of wine, beer, soft drink or water) and bread.  Our...
review_full: We happened across this small restaurant on a visit to Madrid and enjoyed an excellent menu del dia lunch - extremely good value for €10.99 per head which included 3 courses, a drink (a glass of wine, beer, soft drink or water) and bread. Our starters were insalata caprese and cream of broccoli and spinach with croutons, mains were salmon ravioli with cream and courgette sauce and trofie pasta with cherry tomatoes, rocket and parmesan shavings, and desserts of profiteroles and tiramisu. The restaurant filled up very quickly after 2pm with local people working nearby, and I am not surprised it's so popular. We will certainly visit again next time we're in Madrid.

review_preview: It's interesting when you read reviews .... and it just doesn't work out as you expected. This is supposed to be a quality Argentinian Steak House. In reality, the steak was good but the rest of the food wasn't that great and was heavily overpriced...
review_full: It's interesting when you read reviews .... and it just doesn't work out as you expected. This is supposed to be a quality Argentinian Steak House. In reality, the steak was good but the rest of the food wasn't that great and was heavily overpriced considering the quantity and the quality. The worst though was the service: waiters the drop and throw your food on the table and (contrary to what you would expect) cant talk to a tourist in English. Then comes the complimentary this and that, that you didn't ask for, you don't want and in effect (considering the price level) you are surely in reality paying for. I respect different opinions but, in my book, they do not deserve the credit of a good restaurant....be it regarding the food and most especially the atrocious service.

review_preview: This was my first meal in Madrid, and this place looked great. From the outside it looked full, however, the place has a proper sit down restaurant at the back. The staff are fantastic. Very attentive, quick, service with a smile. Nothing was too much...

Very attentive, quick, service with a smile. Nothing was too much trouble. I ordered Sirloin, and a mozzarella cheese, tomatoes and basil salad with a glass on their house Rioja. First I got the bread, and a tomato and cucumber drink, complementary. When I got my food, presentation was good, taste and quality were superb, steak bbq grilled perfectly to medium rare. Texture flavour, and succulents was excellent. Best steak I have had in Spain. Afterwards, even though I. Didn't want a desert I got the lemon sorbet and caramel desert also complementary. I will be coming back for more...........

title_review: Quite the fine dining in Chueca
review_preview: Gioia is a really nice Italian restaurant in Chueca, the service is excellent and the menu is quite innovative, where the innovation by chef Davide Bonato works and tastes great. The decor is subdued and intimate, just the place for a romantic dinner to celebrate....
review_full: Gioia is a really nice Italian restaurant in Chueca, the service is excellent and the menu is quite innovative, where the innovation by chef Davide Bonato works and tastes great. The decor is subdued and intimate, just the place for a romantic dinner to celebrate. We started with a shared La Nostra Burrata (fresh tomatoes and cheese with herbs) with a very good Italian red. Then we had Il Tonno (sesame crusted red tuna filets with ginger and broiled vegetables) and I Tagliolini al tartufo (handmade pasta with truffles, egg and Nero cheese). Both were heavenly, such a mix of textures and tastes. Finished with a wonderful Tiramisu. Highly recommended.

title_review: Lovely restaurant, delightful owners and great food
review_preview: Our friends had been in Madrid a week when we visited and wanted to try Gioia.  The owners, Davide & Daniela, are Italian and were charming hosts. We had Parma ham wrapped around a beef filet, pesto verde, veal Milanease and black ravioli filled with...
review_full: Our friends had been in Madrid a week when we visited and wanted to try Gioia. The owners, Davide & Daniela, are Italian and were charming hosts. We had Parma ham wrapped around a beef filet, pesto verde, veal Milanease and black ravioli filled with shrimp. All were excellent. My wife and I have had tiramisu from Venice to Rome to Naples to Palermo and feel Davide's exceeded the best - Venice - with excellent taste and a wonderful presentation. Enjoy.

review_preview: We dined here on a very hot evening in Madrid and were the only patrons in the restaurant until shortly before we left.  The quietness must have been due to the weather because this restaurant deserves to be full every day of the week. Food...
review_full: We dined here on a very hot evening in Madrid and were the only patrons in the restaurant until shortly before we left. The quietness must have been due to the weather because this restaurant deserves to be full every day of the week.  Food was excellent and beautifully presented.  Tasty amuse bouche on arrival. One of us had the spinach and ricotta ravioli to start followed by a fillet steak. The other a mixed salad followed by the ravioli The pasta is home made and was as good as it gets. Steak was beautifully cooked and artistically plated. Portions were ample.  Check, including a bottle of Mafia di Puglia chardonnay was €100. Highly recommended.

review_preview: Casa de Comidas (House of Foods) is a quite appropriate definition. Everything, starting with the bred which we could smell entering is home made (or at least tastes as such). Very basic terroir food (I had an old style heavy beans soup) mixed with quite...
review_full: Casa de Comidas (House of Foods) is a quite appropriate definition. Everything, starting with the bred which we could smell entering is home made (or at least tastes as such). Very basic terroir food (I had an old style heavy beans soup) mixed with quite elaborated ones (my wife had squid on mesh potatoes mixed with oil and garlic). However, in general is mostly the older generations' menu. Which means tasty and full. Piglets in the oven and tenderloin "on the stone" were more then we should have eat. An interesting "green" wine (vino verde) from Castillia Vieja (the house wine) was quite appropriate with its fresh and dynamic aroma. Beware of deserts. Look fluffy and inoffensive but are impressive. We had a chocolate mousse and a rice batido to be remembered. Pleasant atmosphere, a bit claustrophobic maybe and very friendly service. Need reservations !

title_review: Your food actually looks like the advertisement picture
review_preview: You know how most of the time when you order food it does not look anything like the picture of the advertisement you ordered from? Well, this one actually does!! This place is very unassuming and unpretentious with awesome food and service.They start you...
review_full: You know how most of the time when you order food it does not look anything like the picture of the advertisement you ordered from? Well, this one actually does!!  This place is very unassuming and unpretentious with awesome food and service. They start you off with some bread and chimichurri sauce + some spicy olives. All this on the house!! We ordered the meat platter and a salad. Meat came exactly how we asked for - medium well. They were all falvorful and succulent. Salad was very fresh with a slightly sweet sauce which went perfectly with all that meat (see pictures of the platter and the salad).  We also ordered desert, a piece of cake with layers of goodness, forgot the name!! But they also bring you a glass of what taste like lemon sorbet which was good, again on the house (see pictures of the cake and the complimentary desert).  Staff burly spoke English. So what happened was that we could not finish our platter and told our waitress to box it up for take away. However, although she said ok ok, she tossed our food away. What gives them a 5 star for the service though is that, once they realized this mistake, they remade a small box of food for us to take a away - when they could have very well said, sorry there is nothing we can do about it!! Go to this place. Do not feel guilty about not eating 'Spanish food' only on your trip. There is so much Jambon and tapas one can take before steak and fresh salad becomes necessary ;) Bon appetite

title_review: A very memorable dinner with amazing services
review_preview: We picked this restaurant because it is a few minutes’ walk from our hotel, TripAdvisor has good reviews, and the hotel receptionist highly recommended it.  We were very impressed with the service and food.  There were four of us and we like to share dishes....
review_full: We picked this restaurant because it is a few minutes’ walk from our hotel, TripAdvisor has good reviews, and the hotel receptionist highly recommended it. We were very impressed with the service and food. There were four of us and we like to share dishes. They gave us new plates for each dish we ordered and in many cases, they split the dish for us. It was like having a 5-6 courses dinner. More importantly, the waiter recommended squid stuffed with codfish. This was a very memorable dish; I highly recommend it if you are going to have dinner here. The other dishes we like very much include Monk Fish, Oxtail stew, fish and seafood soup, and thin apple cake with ice cream.

review_preview: The slogan of Dantxari is "La cocina vasca de siempre", which I'd loosely translate as "The traditional basque cuisine" and the restaurant does not belie its slogan. Conservatively decorated with an attentive 'old school' service this is a safe bet if you want to have...
review_full: The slogan of Dantxari is "La cocina vasca de siempre", which I'd loosely translate as "The traditional basque cuisine" and the restaurant does not belie its slogan. Conservatively decorated with an attentive 'old school' service this is a safe bet if you want to have a nice, basque style meal but will not break new grounds, neither in the presentation nor in the kitchen.  Sometimes this is a good thing and nowadays I'd rather have a place like this, where nothing disappoints, over another 'cool', trendy and completely interchangeable restaurant. I had a tasty gazpacho and a very nice fish (neither are on the standard menu). In both cases the food was one notch or two above a normal restaurant but staid just short of the gourmet level. The glass of white wine (had to drive) was also fine. Overall a nice solid performance. It should be underlined that the ground level restaurant is smoke-free which is a big plus for me. The menu is also available in English and French and some of the staff clearly speak English. It's location close to the 'Princesa' group of arthouse cinemas will probably mean that I will return from time to time to Dantxari and I look forward to that.

review_preview: Two of us had dinner at Dantxari and had a very enjoyable time. The atmosphere was very low key and friendly, the place was full, and the table was ours for the evening to sit and chat.We started with the tomato-based gazpacho, which was...
review_full: Two of us had dinner at Dantxari and had a very enjoyable time. The atmosphere was very low key and friendly, the place was full, and the table was ours for the evening to sit and chat. We started with the tomato-based gazpacho, which was excellent. We were given a choice of chopped vegetables to include in the finely puréed soup. Our decision to include all of the offered choices turned out well. Our entree choice was a sliced filet of beef with a mustard sauce. It was cooked to our requirements and served with potato slices and sauteed green vegetables. Portions were generous. The entree was more like very good home cooking than the more fussy version likely to be served at a high-end restaurant. For dessert one of us chose from among their interesting flavors of ice cream and the other a large dish of fresh fruit. We each had a glass of decent and quite reasonably priced Rioja with the meal.

review_preview: We did not plan to eat here, nor had we checked any reviews. The menu posted in front looked good so we took our chances. I'm so glad we did. We had three of the best dishes we've had since our travels in Europe began...
review_full: We did not plan to eat here, nor had we checked any reviews. The menu posted in front looked good so we took our chances. I'm so glad we did. We had three of the best dishes we've had since our travels in Europe began three weeks ago. We ordered the duck liver pate, pork beef cheeks, and oxtails - just half portions since we wanted to share them. Everything was fabulous. The pate was rich and creamy without being over-seasoned. The pork cheeks were tender with a peppery gravy, and the oxtails were the highlight of the meal - fall-apart tender with a savory wine sauce. Wonderful ambience and nonstop great service rounded out the experience. Perfect!

review_preview: Had dinner here with my husband.  The restaurant was highly recommended by Hipólito at the Marriott Princesa hotel.  The service was excellent.  Danilo and Jaime were our very attentive servers.  Danilo went over much of the menu in both Spanish and English.  We ordered the...
review_full: Had dinner here with my husband. The restaurant was highly recommended by Hipólito at the Marriott Princesa hotel. The service was excellent. Danilo and Jaime were our very attentive servers. Danilo went over much of the menu in both Spanish and English. We ordered the sweet roasted green peppers with crunchy salt sprinkled on top. It was a huge plate and I figured we’d never finish them...but we did because they were so good. For our entree, we shared the corvino, which was very good once I sprinkled some lemon juice over it. We also had flan with raspberry sauce, which was very good. The people next to us had the oxtail that smelled absolutely delicious, which they said it definitely was. That’s what I’d get if we come back again on another trip. Danilo added on another dessert, complements of the house, which was a very crispy pastry in the shape of a tunnel, and also offered an after-dinner aperitif at no charge, which was very nice of him. We also met the owner, Jesus, who was very welcoming. It was a very nice evening.

review_preview: I highly recommend if you want a non-tourist restaurant frequented by residents of Madrid.  The venue is small/family run with a cozy atmosphere.  If my wife could have come, this would have been a great date location.  Most importantly, the food was amazing!  The staff...
review_full: I highly recommend if you want a non-tourist restaurant frequented by residents of Madrid. The venue is small/family run with a cozy atmosphere. If my wife could have come, this would have been a great date location. Most importantly, the food was amazing! The staff was very friendly bringing a tasty chorizo and fresh bread to start our dinner followed by fish croquettes, that we ordered, also very good! Although I don’t drink, a work colleague assured me that the wine list was extensive and interesting. For main courses, we ordered a code fillet with butter gravy, a bean and tripe stew and beef with mustard gravy. We all shared bites but I’m not sure which was better as all were outstanding! Although the main courses were enough food, we had to try deserts so split an order or rice pudding and an order of truffles. End of the day, this restaurant is a find! I’ll be back.

review_preview: Great way to take a break from the usual tapas fare. It's meat. Order as sandwiches or just as meat. You'll be glad you did. We got the Duo - basically a sampler of all their meats, with slices of several different cuts of steak...
review_full: Great way to take a break from the usual tapas fare. It's meat. Order as sandwiches or just as meat. You'll be glad you did. We got the Duo - basically a sampler of all their meats, with slices of several different cuts of steak and a couple of different sausages. All very flavorful. Also served with bread and tomato/mozarella skewers. Plenty of smaller options if you just want a taste or small typical tapas-sized portion. And if you want to do more of a tapas crawl, it happens to be very close to several other nice places, all just steps away from Puerta del Sol. We actually had planned on hitting several different places, but ended up just staying at Bayres. The sangria pitcher was great and a good deal. The service was top-notch friendly. You can sit inside or out, though I'd recommend outside for great people watching - it's a lively area at night. Moral of the story: it's meat. Great meat.

We were served by an Italian girl called Alessandra - she was working before starting her erasmus. I think she needs to be hired as a consultant to teach Spanish waiting staff how good service is supposed to be delivered. In fact she gave me and my friend some of the best service I have ever had in any restaurant anywhere!

review_preview: Went here with my wife and some friends who recommended it, it was a fine choice.  The bar in front is hopping at Tapas Time (21:15) on July 11, 2011, I guess the folks nearby like to "tapear" and drink here. Went to the dining...
review_full: Went here with my wife and some friends who recommended it, it was a fine choice. The bar in front is hopping at Tapas Time (21:15) on July 11, 2011, I guess the folks nearby like to "tapear" and drink here. Went to the dining room in the back and counted 8 tables with room for about 35 to 40 customers max. We did have the red tuna to start and it was delicious, we then had the magnificent fillet steak with pepper sauce and the Muga Rioja Wine at 29 Euros per bottle, it was wonderful also! Ambience its not but I'd rather eat well then eat badly in a fancy/shmansie place. My only complaint is that enroute from the bar to the restaurant you pass the rest rooms which really small of disinfectant otherwise, no complaints! Bill for 2, 85 Euros with wine included. Make a reservation!

review_preview: We made a reservation in advance for Saturday night diner, which is an absolute must. The restaurant consists out of a veeeeery busy bar in front, and a room with relaxing atmosphere in the back where dinner is served. Our waitress was friendly despite lacking...
review_full: We made a reservation in advance for Saturday night diner, which is an absolute must. The restaurant consists out of a veeeeery busy bar in front, and a room with relaxing atmosphere in the back where dinner is served. Our waitress was friendly despite lacking a good knowledge of English. An English menu is available upon request. My boyfriend and I wanted to try the suggestion menu for 39€ each, which consisted out of 7 dishes. Service was very swift and correct. Looking back, I believe this menu was one of the best price-quality we ever had so far! First dish consisted out of duck liver with fine slices of mango. A strange combination at first sight, but so delicious! Next were the jamon with tomato, a succulent fried gamba and piece of tuna, all three of them very delicious. First main course was a very tasty piece of merluza (the spanish cod) with vegetables followed by a meat course with deer and duck liver (a strange dish to be served in Spring, but oh so yummy!). Prices for drinks were ridiculously cheap: 2,5€ for a glass of very tasty brut Cava. We finished around 100€ for the 2 menu's, bread and oil service, 4 glasses of cava, 2 glasses of wine, 2 bottles of sparkling water and 1 cappucino / cola. Do not miss this gem when visiting Madrid!
