title_review: Lovely restaurant with good dishes and very good service
review_preview: When you are led past the bustling bar where patrons enjoy good tapas and wines, you enter a serene, beautiful dining room tastefully done in all white.  A misto fritto amuse bouche was generous and brought different seafood perfectly fried.  Together with a terrine of...
review_full: When you are led past the bustling bar where patrons enjoy good tapas and wines, you enter a serene, beautiful dining room tastefully done in all white.  A misto fritto amuse bouche was generous and brought different seafood perfectly fried. Together with a terrine of rabbit, it made for a great start. We loved the gazpacho version and a rich pheasant salad, the earthy pheasant sauce coating the greens in lieu of a dressing. Also very good: the venison dried meat and the ortiguillas marinas, fried sea anemone (we loved the oceanic taste of those little fried balls). The dessert variety also offers pleasurable selections as does the varied wine list with excellent prices. Service is attentive and friendly. This is a lovely restaurant.

title_review: Delicious, delightful introduction to Spanish cuisine
review_preview: As a first time visitor to Madrid, I was uncertain about my first venture into the cuisine. Dentxari (den-SAR-ee) is a charming and warm deep dive into the many splendors of Spanish food. The dining room on the first floor has a bistro-like feel, with...
review_full: As a first time visitor to Madrid, I was uncertain about my first venture into the cuisine. Dentxari (den-SAR-ee) is a charming and warm deep dive into the many splendors of Spanish food. The dining room on the first floor has a bistro-like feel, with a dark wood bar in the corner, and hewn wood beams. The warmth of the staff is felt immediately, and the maitre 'd, hearing that we were not Spanish made sure that we had English menus (Thank you!). My wife savored the white asparagus entree, while I learned the intense, smoky delight of cured ham (jamon). The mains were at the same high standard or better! My wife's Hake was beautifully presented with an rich, flavorful seafood reduction, and my squab (pichon) was perfectly roasted, carved and presented in a delicious mushroom sauce. The presentations were interesting and thoughtful without being over-wrought. We finished by splitting a rice pudding that was not too sweet, and laced with bright orange zest; refreshing and pleasing. Another thing we enjoyed was that we could hear each other! We were there on a Saturday night, and while the room was full, we were able to have an audible conversation, while the unobtrusive, but efficient staff seemed to appear at just the right moment.

Our waiter helped us with what to order, as there were three of us we got the platter of 3 steaks, 2 sausages and bread with their own sauce. We also got a side salad and Empanadas. We asked for the steak rare and got it rare - was amazing! The beef just melted in your mouth and the platter served all three of us perfectly! They even chucked in an extra Empanada and couple drinks at the end of the meal. Such a perfect little restaurant and such good value!  The food did come on environmentally friendly plates but this didn't matter as the food was so good! Already recommended this to friends!

review_preview: I've been wanting to go to this Basque restaurant in our neighborhood since we moved here.  We went on a Sunday afternoon...family day in Madrid.  We totally lucked out getting a table without a reservation.  Many large groups of families were there...it was fun to...
review_full: I've been wanting to go to this Basque restaurant in our neighborhood since we moved here. We went on a Sunday afternoon...family day in Madrid. We totally lucked out getting a table without a reservation. Many large groups of families were there...it was fun to watch them. You can tell they frequent this place and the wait staff knew them. Great atmosphere, lovely place, very friendly wait staff, great house wine. For appetizers, we ordered two 1/2 rations: the cod croquettas and the anchovies to share. They were both incredible. I'd go back just for those. For our mains, I got the 1/2 ration of cod and my husband got the 1/2 ration of the ox tail stew. His was fantastic and mine was very good. The sauces are so tasty. Looking around at what other people ordered...it all looked great. The portions were very generous and everything (including bread) will fill you up. We wanted dessert, but didn't have room. We ordered cafe con leche which came with a large, curved almond cracker (which was like a dessert). The head waiter/owner came out and spoke with us and brought us the traditional after dinner drink. Don't be in a hurry...family lunch lasts about 3 hours....and costs about 30 euro/pp. What a great way to spend a Sunday afternoon. We'll be back, with friends (and we'll be sure to make a reservation).

review_full: We had a great meal at this lovely restaurant near our hotel. Small, homey-feeling and full of locals (they were still coming to eat, even families, at 9:30!) as well as visitors. They started us with a "small" bite- 2 delicious sausages- as we finally whittled our choices down (the English menu helped). We chose the pâté and the awesome pickled quail salad (Codorniz), the sea bass and monkfish (rape) and the delightful apple cake- that's a "don't miss"! Our waiter was very helpful in suggesting portion sizes and a delicious red wine that perfectly accented the food. Between his halting English and our schoolbook Spanish, we did just fine, and the service was good. As an extra treat, they served us a thin crunchy after-dinner treat called a Teja (shaped like a roof tile) and an interesting liqueur. The prices were reasonable. We left very full and very happy; we highly recommend this restaurant.

review_full: The restaurant is small and easy to miss. If it's your first time and you don't have cell phone access in Madrid, you can download an off-line map and navigate to it. We walked from the Sol subway station. We had steaks and Argentine chorizo both times. They also have tasty empanadas. Their beef is imported from Argentina. The steak sauce (chimichurri) was excellent.  This is a budget restaurant. My wife and I ate for around 30 Euros. This is half the price of many nicer restaurants. The price doesn't include fancy table cloths, real plates and silverware. The restaurant is small, efficient, and both times the service was excellent. Our waiter Santiago was attentive and his menu recommendations were outstanding.

All of this alongside a bottle of water and 4 glasses of wine came to approx. 40-43 euros. Such great value for money and great service.

title_review: Excellent Basque cuisine with attentive and friendly service
review_preview: I'd like to describe this restaurant as "classical" but I fear that might put some people off. But it IS classical in the sense that all the boxes get ticked: well selected produce is prepared and presented with care, with attentive and helpful front-of-house staff...
review_full: I'd like to describe this restaurant as "classical" but I fear that might put some people off. But it IS classical in the sense that all the boxes get ticked: well selected produce is prepared and presented with care, with attentive and helpful front-of-house staff ready to speed everything to your table. Basque cuisine is based on fresh meats, fish and seasonal vegetables. Here too, the menu reflects that background. My wife and I have dined here four times and we still have yet to cover the full range on the menu. The wine lists are detailed and wide-ranging, with some rather ordinary wines nestled in among the better ones. And being Basque there is some cider too. One tip: if you would like to try the Dantxari's renowned rendering of apple tart, order it at the beginning of your meal: it takes a while to prepare... and is worth the wait. Another tip: even in these economically depressed times it is best to book a table in advance. At weekends it is essential.

Service was great, always attentive but not overly so. And we were offered a free shot after the meal. Highly recommend a visit.

review_preview: This is the type of restaurant that gets repeat visitors. It is a haunt for many Madrileños, and those, like my wife and I who live further south in the country, return on culture trips.Basque people eat well, and the menu at Dantxari reflects...
review_full: This is the type of restaurant that gets repeat visitors. It is a haunt for many Madrileños, and those, like my wife and I who live further south in the country, return on culture trips. Basque people eat well, and the menu at Dantxari reflects this. Hearty meat and fish dishes that reflect the lifestyle of those who live on Spain's north coast, are what are highlighted here. Service is swift, sure, friendly and yet unobtrusive. The advice of the maitre d', the sommeliere and probably all of the waiting staff, is excellent. What to ask for? Well, tastes differ from person to person, but we like their traditional sausages, their codfish dishes and their steak tartare. In winter their stews are highly recommended. The wine list is exhaustive, with good value wines as well as some that are harder to find (and thus more expensive) elsewhere. A final tip: at the very outset, tell your table server that you would like Dantxari's famed apple tart. This takes time to prepare, so if you forget, it might be too late to order later on. This delight is wafer thin and extremely habit forming. (Now you know one of the reasons why my wife and I return so often).

title_review: Bayres Beef; Great Place to Enjoy Great Steak !
review_preview: There are several reviews of Bayres Beef and most are vague and incomplete. I'll try to be as complete as possible and say right from the start: You'll love this place!  So lets start at the beginning. Bayres Steak is a small Argentinian steak house,...
review_full: There are several reviews of Bayres Beef and most are vague and incomplete. I'll try to be as complete as possible and say right from the start: You'll love this place! So lets start at the beginning. Bayres Steak is a small Argentinian steak house, small meaning that the inside of the restaurant consists of a nice sized grill and three small tables for two. Now please don't let that sway you unless you're looking for a dining experience with candlelight and romance. Bayres has many nice sidewalk tables for four. You come here in the evening to enjoy the air, a bottle of wine and some great steak. Bring your sweetheart, sit down, and let Miguel your waiter, cater to you and offer some great suggestions to try. We tried the large sliced steak shown in the photo which was accompanied by two skewers of cherry tomato and mozzarella. We also ordered Chorizo sausage and a bottle of the Rioja. The Chiorzo was quite good and the steak was nicely grilled and very flavorful. We finished the steak and because it was so good, we ordered another one, but a smaller size. Afterwards we were offered a complimentary homemade cordial which was amazing. Lastly we had some chocolate cake and coffee... Total cost, about 45 euros. We stayed several hours dining here on the sidewalk, We enjoyed the food and Miguel's hospitality. We came back again another day and swapped the Chorizo for some Empanada which also was really tasty. Please don't let the idea that you have to eat outside and with paper plates turn you away.... You'll be missing a great experience if you do. We will come back again !

review_full: I had been to Dantxari before with a large group -- usually not the best way of assessing a restaurant. It was nevertheless a very positive experience. I have now gone back, and we were just two. It was again a very good experience, with a welcoming, classical service. The food was very good, with huge servings of very fresh fish. The setting is "traditional", nothing fancy or "elegant", but certainly pleasant. The prices are in line with the local standards. It's certainly a place I'll keep going back to.

review_preview: I'm giving this 5 stars due to the service and the food (4.5). Dantxari was recommended by a friend who is from Madrid, so to have a place noted by a local is always worth a try. My husband an I were very satisfied from...
review_full: I'm giving this 5 stars due to the service and the food (4.5). Dantxari was recommended by a friend who is from Madrid, so to have a place noted by a local is always worth a try. My husband an I were very satisfied from start to finish. I recommend the duck liver starter and monk fish ( a substantial piece) Basque style. Although much of the menu looked to our liking. The service was extremely attentive with out being overbearing and felt like we were returning to the restaurant as regulars. I suggest making a reservation (we were there on Saturday) as it was completely full when we left.  If you're tired of the tapas scene and want to enjoy delicious Basque cuisine then Dantxari will not disappoint.

We ordered a meat empanada to start which was perfect in every way. Then we had the sausage and the Entricote steak. They were delicious. The chimichurri sauce served with it was great. As we finished the owner came over to see how our food was and chatted with us. Gave us a bit of the history of the restaurant which we love to hear. Then he offered us some desert shots on the house. So sweet. Highly recommend this place if you like quality meet for a very reasonable price.

review_preview: Today we spent our last day in Madrid - so we decided to go out to a more expensive restaurant. The Parilla de Maria did look pretty good from outside, so we have choosed to give it a shot. We have ordered pasta stuffed with...
review_full: Today we spent our last day in Madrid - so we decided to go out to a more expensive restaurant. The Parilla de Maria did look pretty good from outside, so we have choosed to give it a shot. We have ordered pasta stuffed with salmon and gamba-sauce (~17€) and wine(~17€). According to the prices, we expeceted a high quality dish but we were highly disappointed.  The portions we received were ridiculously small, so our plates weren't even half full. There were only like 8 tortelloni and 3 half(!!! yes, i said half) gambas on it. The sauce was ok but to call it a gamba-sauce is totally rip-off. The salmon-stuffing also tasted quite dry which made this visit a perfect waste of money. After we finished our dish we went on finishing our bottle of wine. The Service obviously wanted us to clear the table and constantly looked very mean at us when passing by and checked every 10 minutes nerved our bottle of wine if it's finished. As a customer that makes you feel very uncomfortable.  We are three persons, all students at the age of 25, so maybe they have taken us as a cheap knoff off customer which makes the restaurant even less recommendable.  There are so many restaurants in Madrid which are way more better in quality and price. So my advice to you: Spent your money and your hunger in a different restaurant. You won't miss anything if you don't got to this location.

Between our host and the couple seated next to us we ordered what turned out to be a great meal. The servering sizes were very large and we could have shared one entre and a salad. Beef was cooked perfectly and side items as well. We ultimately ate once more at the bar and twice in the restaurant where Nancy and Juana gave us exceptional service. The bar is great fun and the restaurant is more quiet. Best lighting we have ever experienced. Lots of extras in the restaurant included. We wish this place was in our neighborhood!

review_preview: I went three times whilst in Madrid it was that good.  Elsewhere in Spain found service particularly slow at the best of times.  Not in Parilla De Maria's - top level service all the way.   And the food, menu options as well as drink proportions...
review_full: I went three times whilst in Madrid it was that good. Elsewhere in Spain found service particularly slow at the best of times. Not in Parilla De Maria's - top level service all the way. And the food, menu options as well as drink proportions very generous. I got really spoilt with olives & chips as an appertiser, then bread with dips & then the actual food that I ordered. Freebies didn't stop there either - was treated to quite a few sangrias and Henricks gin & lemonades over the course of my three visits. Even though staff didn't speak much english - they were very accommodating and did their very best to make me feel like I was part of the spanish family, so to speak. I would recommend this restaurant to anyone visiting Madrid - central location and even though some reviews said it was a bit pricey - every cent spent was well worth it!! Give it a go for sure..........

review_preview: We traveled to Spain with family this summer and stayed in Madrid in Carlos V, a Best Western hotel. Not all of us enjoy seafood and found ourselves with difficulty finding foods we could all enjoy at a restaurant.. The hotel manager recommended De Maria....
review_full: We traveled to Spain with family this summer and stayed in Madrid in Carlos V, a Best Western hotel. Not all of us enjoy seafood and found ourselves with difficulty finding foods we could all enjoy at a restaurant.. The hotel manager recommended De Maria. Off we went since it was walking distance... and we hit the jackpot! The appetizer of Manchego cheese was perfect. We all had different entrees. My husband had the meat, my daughter had chicken, her boyfriend had seafood and I stuck with the pesto pasta. Wow. Noone was disappointed! Dessert was tiramisu and the chocolate cake with the mint sauce. Oh my goodness.... Great sangria and wine, too. It was definitely pricey but we were on vacation and like to eat well. We are of Spanish descent so yes, the staff was comfortable carrying a conversation with us. We are also a talkative foursome so they had no choice but to stick around and talk to us! Unlike some of you, we did not get any freebies at the end of dinner but we also weren't charged extra for sitting outside. The inside was pretty cramped so we stayed outside so we could people watch (which is a treat by itself). We went back a second time and enjoyed it just as much. Don't pass this restaurant up and even if you don't speak the language very well, engage them and learn about the culture by talking to them.

title_review: The best meal that we had in Spain (and every meal was delicious)
review_preview: If you are looking for a fine-dining experience near Parque de el Retiro, La monteria will provide a delicious meal in a warm, cozy atmosphere. The restaurant is very small, so you need to book in advance. I knew that it would be a great...
review_full: If you are looking for a fine-dining experience near Parque de el Retiro, La monteria will provide a delicious meal in a warm, cozy atmosphere. The restaurant is very small, so you need to book in advance. I knew that it would be a great meal after we were served delicious bread and a small basket of deep-fried anchovies and calamari. My wife and I opted for the a la carte menu after being assured that the portions were large enough, and all three courses were inventive, beautifully plated, and even tastier than they were pretty. And the portions definitely were large enough. I started with the boletus con huevos trufados, which is a mushroom dish topped with a perfectly poached egg. This was followed by tuna, which was served appropriately rare but also has a nice char on one face. While my wife and I were both full, we had to get dessert, and the bunuelos de chocolate (chocolate donuts) melt in your mouth. It was a memorable meal, and we will be back if we return to Madrid A few tips for diners: We ordered from the a la carte menu since my wife is pregnant and could not eat the raw tuna that I ordered, but a few tables around us had opted for the tasting menu, which was served family style and both looked and smelled delicious. The portions also seemed large, so you definitely won't go hungry. Also, while it might not be on the menu, the restaurant has very affordable and tasty glasses of house wine if you are not with enough people to order a bottle.

We had the lascas de foie with mango and crujiente, arroz con rape and rabo de toro deshuesado. The rice was somewhat disappointing in my opinion but the other two dishes were really good. For dessert we had the torrija which was also very nice. What I really loved is that as we were sharing they brought everything already split in two dishes and the portions were generous so we could try a few different things. It is clear that they put care into small details such as this. The wine list is also extensive so a great place to find some variety to go with the food.

title_review: One of my favorite food places in Madrid
review_preview: Each time I've been to Madrid I payed Bayres Beef a visit and I was never disappointed. It is centrally located, about 100m away from Sol. The venue is rather small, but the taste and quality of the food served is BIIIIG! It has actually...
review_full: Each time I've been to Madrid I payed Bayres Beef a visit and I was never disappointed. It is centrally located, about 100m away from Sol. The venue is rather small, but the taste and quality of the food served is BIIIIG! It has actually become one of my favorite places for food in Madrid.  You can order anything meaty (which is the main reason why you would like to go there ;-) it's Argentinian meat by the way!) from the menu either in a bread roll or as a tapa (which makes it easier to share among a couple of friends). They also have great meat pies, as well as some vegetarian options.  If you go there don't forget to order the housemade chocolate cake for dessert! It's so good you want to have another one, although you're already full!

Order the melted provolone cheese with ham, tomato and oregano...its definetly something your taste buds wll thank you for!

review_full: We stayed at the Europa just down the street. At first glance El Gaucho looked like just a bar stool restaurant, but my wife noticed that they also had salon seating. I went in and tried to make reservations for 9 and had to settle for 10 which is no problem in Spain. The first night we had the Gaucho meal for 2. It was outstanding. The service was great. They started with several glasses of Cava and ceviche, which we did not anticipate. The meal was unbelievable. We were full and could not order a dessert. However, the waitress brought several nice post dinner nice mini desserts followed by a couple of glasses of Ourujo de Hierbas liquor. We were so impressed we made reservations for the next night and this time ordered the steak for two. The meat was outstanding. This time in addition to all the extras they left the bottle of Orujo on the table for us to enjoy. If I ever go back to to Madrid I will head straight to El Gaucho!

title_review: As Good as a Meal Can Be
review_preview: Some meals are so good that you can only say they are among the best.  Each is different and hard to compare.  The Menu Classico at La Monteria falls in this category.  It is refined and exquisite food at a very fair price.  After a...
review_full: Some meals are so good that you can only say they are among the best. Each is different and hard to compare. The Menu Classico at La Monteria falls in this category. It is refined and exquisite food at a very fair price. After a lovely aperitif, the meal started with several tasty appetizers: mango+foie gras, iberian ham & parmesan, a cleverly done tiger shrimp, red tuna, and on to more substantial dishes including a wonderful venison loin in a red wine reduction. Every one of the dishes was exquisite. The service was very attentive and they offered some lovely after dinner drinks. And as a bonus, there was great people watching. For a special meal, this is the place.

We opted for the menu of the day which was a starter, main course, coffee or dessert and a glass of wine or beer for around 19 euros per person which represented fantastic value for money. However, on top of this, we were brought delicious bread with little dips, gazpacho and a kind of fruity sorbet drink during the meal, all complimentary. The food was hot and tasty, and although the main course let it down slightly, the rest of the food and the high quality attention to detail more than made up for this. Would highly recommend.

review_preview: We wanted to go to Vila Brasil but felt it was too far out so we chose El Gaucho somewhat reluctantly. We were in for a surprise as it was a great night. It´s easy to feel you have come to the wrong place from...
review_full: We wanted to go to Vila Brasil but felt it was too far out so we chose El Gaucho somewhat reluctantly. We were in for a surprise as it was a great night. It´s easy to feel you have come to the wrong place from the outside and the bar area but the restaurant at the back is a class act. It was lovely to be given a glass of cava rose each and then came the little toasts and the cheese dip along with shot glasses with pumpkin soup and some quality fresh warm bread and breadsticks all on the house. We ordered the parillada for three and as my wife doesn´t like blood on her meat they offered to cook half of the meat medium well. We ordered a Caesar salad to start with and it was pretty perfect with a sharp dressing and quite beautifully presented. The silver dish full of meats duly arrived along with some excellent asparagus from the brasa and a big plate of chips along with a choice of sauces. There was enough meat for at least one more person possibly two and if we return we will order for two rather than the three of us. The meats were cooked exactly as they were supposed to be and were good quality. The asparagus was worth writing a letter home about. We were far too full for deserts however the waitress insisted that she bring us some more offerings on the house including a delicious kiwi yoghurt and a Cava sorbet along with a bottle of something alcoholic to clear the palate. The bill came to a touch less than €100 and was extremely good value for money. I understand people giving this restaurant five star reviews and I agree that it really is a great experience but five stars for me has to be something absolutely extraordinary.

You have a bread with a beautiful sauce/dressing, then a chorizo sausage as starter, a 125grm (roughly) steak with fries and then an ice cream (I had chocolate). title_review: A fine Grill house in Madrid
review_preview: Based on the reviews here in TripAdvisor I chose El Gaucho for my first dinner in Madrid and once again our fellow travelers reviews were proven absolutely spot on. We ordered the Argentinean mix for 2, baked potatoes, grilled peppers and a Mediterranean salad. All...
review_full: Based on the reviews here in TripAdvisor I chose El Gaucho for my first dinner in Madrid and once again our fellow travelers reviews were proven absolutely spot on. We ordered the Argentinean mix for 2, baked potatoes, grilled peppers and a Mediterranean salad. All were excellent ! The service was very discreet and attentive and the quality and quantity of the “on the house” treats they provided (sparkling wine and cheese dip for starters, chocolate moose, lemon sorbet and lemon liquor at the end) completed the excellent impression. It didn’t come cheap, 65€ for two people, but it was absolutely worth it.

review_preview: Great little restaurant full of Spanish families, clearly regulars (always a good sign when you're the only English) just next door to Mercure Plaza de Espana hotel. review_full: Great little restaurant full of Spanish families, clearly regulars (always a good sign when you're the only English) just next door to Mercure Plaza de Espana hotel. Great atmosphere, cheerful decor (red check tablecloths, wood, pottery on the walls), very welcoming staff, good wine list. Lots of dishes on the menu which I didn't know (English menu available), all made fresh with good quality ingredients, good portions (I had the half portions on starter and main, both more than adequate for me). I booked through 'the Fork' booking service and said I was gluten free (sin gluten), they had gluten free bread waiting for me and told me when I ordered one of the dishes had a small amount of flour in the sauce which was great. Would happily eat here again.

Then the deserts be it cinnamon ice cream or frozen truffle sorbet were excellent in taste and left a clear pallet. A complimentary after dinner wine was served topping of a meal to remember. For the quality 68E was excellent value and you left having had a delightful experience eating quality food

The entrance is a little kitschy, but the main dinner area is nice, in a modern style. The food and specifically the steak was very good. The first time they offered a very tasty soup, on the house. The staff was very friendly. The price came to about 40-50 euros per person. I guess it is not a place for tight budgets and it has a "cosmopolitan" rather than a traditional Spanish style. We obviously had a good time and we went back one more time. The convenient location is a big plus.

title_review: I would live at Dantxari if i could!
review_preview: We enjoyed (understatement) an evening at Dantxari with our Spanish family.  It was THE BEST.  From appetizers to dessert and the accompanying cordials, it was truly a "bucket list" type experience.  The service was exceptional and the food equaled the service.  Beyond expectations.  We loved...
review_full: We enjoyed (understatement) an evening at Dantxari with our Spanish family. It was THE BEST. From appetizers to dessert and the accompanying cordials, it was truly a "bucket list" type experience. The service was exceptional and the food equaled the service. Beyond expectations. We loved the cozy yet comfortable dining room with attentive, yet not smothering, service. We were made to feel at home and valued. It was beyond anything we have experienced in the U.S.A. and we have enjoyed some fine East Coast restaurants. Our group had everything from the stuffed hake to the oxtail stew for our entrees. The desserts were also exceptional: sorbete, tejas, and more. It was fascinating to try all the after dinner cordials from various parts of Spain. We had wanted to go back again, but found they were closed the day we had available. Sad for us! We cannot wait to go back and intend to visit Dantxari every time we are in Madrid which we hope is often!

title_review: Must go to fully experience Spain!
review_preview: The 1st day we arrived in Madrid, we were so hungry and showed up at Dantxari for a late lunch/early dinner (~5p). We didn't realize the kitchen was closed since there were 2 groups still enjoying conversation and drinks. It was a pleasant surprise that...
review_full: The 1st day we arrived in Madrid, we were so hungry and showed up at Dantxari for a late lunch/early dinner (~5p). We didn't realize the kitchen was closed since there were 2 groups still enjoying conversation and drinks. It was a pleasant surprise that Jesus accommodated us with appetizers that were a delight. The service, atmosphere and food were superb. We had a great time and we were told to take our time and enjoy, there was no rush. It was a wonderful experience, we went back the next day for lunch and again everything was excellent. You can't go wrong with what you order. We suggest trying the sangria, any of the salads, and the solomillo de cerdo (meat) , which is delicious and like butter. Their specialty is meat and fish. To clean the palate after dinner, try the teja, which is light and sweet. And send our regards to Evaristo and Jesus. Enjoy!

The food is wonderful, with the ability to get two half portions of different entrees, if you desire. We had the cod croquettes, the seafood and fish pudding, and the special pardon-like peppers for appetizers...and the magnificent special turbot for two as our entrée. Everything, and I mean everything, was superb. We have made another reservation in about a week when we return from our 5-day trip to San Sebastian for more wonderful food. We can't wait to have the pig's feet next time!!!

title_review: Excellent food and attentive service - top choice
review_preview: We visited for dinner on Good Friday. The city was busy with Easter celebrations and the restaurant was buzzing. We were shown to a very pleasant table by the window. Helpful staff were very patient with our stilted Spanish. We received a complimentary glass of...
review_full: We visited for dinner on Good Friday. The city was busy with Easter celebrations and the restaurant was buzzing. We were shown to a very pleasant table by the window. Helpful staff were very patient with our stilted Spanish. We received a complimentary glass of pink cava and enjoyed delicious food. The service was prompt but not rushed and all in all good value for money. We enjoyed so much we went back for a second visit. The front of house manager remembered us and the service was superb. Good for meat lovers but I had a vegetarian pasta dish on my second visit and that was lovely too. recommended and a much better option than the tourist trap cafes and restaurants in Plaza Mayor.

We sat at one of their half dozen tables in the street to take in the atmosphere of the tight Madrid streets surrounding it. The service was very friendly and the food, well as the headline says "I'm not usually a steak man but if it all tasted this good that would soon change". We shared the duo option on the menu - three cuts of steak plus sausage then added rocket salad and a ridiculously tasty jacket potato to or order. Everything was excellent and done to perfection...the only thing wrong on the evening for our Argentinian hosts was the result of the football.

title_review: High quality cuisine at a reasonable price.
review_preview: Service very good, limited English but provided English menuWine list very good, Spanish Three house whites, had a glass each of Rueda then a bottle of Aalto (Ribera del Duero), which was excellent. Ambience: cozy with red checked tables. Had a menu available for...
review_full: Service very good, limited English but provided English menu Wine list very good, Spanish  Three house whites, had a glass each of Rueda then a bottle of Aalto (Ribera del Duero), which was excellent.  Ambience: cozy with red checked tables.  Had a menu available for 65E including wine (one glass? Not sure) - I think there were half a dozen courses. But we had checked out the menu earlier in the day and were set on having the monkfish in a garlic sauce and grilled sea bass in tomato (sauce?). As a starter we shared a salad with goat cheese (beautiful cheese), greens (Belgian endive, frisée and field greens) with a tomato or fig compote and an onion marmalade...truly wonderful! The fish was fresh and perfectly done. We gilded the lily by ordering dessert - not the famous apple cake but the white chocolate mousse with orange sauce and the Pedro Ximenez ice cream. Delicious! With our coffee we were served the giant almond "cookie" mentioned previously.

review_preview: We came here on recommendation. 2 adults, sat inside as it was a windy night.  The restaurant aphid only 1 table full as it was only 7pm.  Service was average for the time we were there.  We ordered 2 steaks and a plate of broccoli...
review_full: We came here on recommendation. 2 adults, sat inside as it was a windy night. The restaurant aphid only 1 table full as it was only 7pm. Service was average for the time we were there. We ordered 2 steaks and a plate of broccoli and potatoes. The veg/potatoes arrived and no sign of the meat. When I asked, I was told that this comes first!! Wish I had been told earlier as I would have explained I wanted it together and the menu doesn't explain this either. Anyway the veg is now cold when the steaks arrive. I had asked for well done, it was rare, still with blood coming out and my husband wanted rare but it was blue, sill mooing I suspect. To be fair, my husband said he would eat his and I asked to send mine back, something I would never normally do. By the time it arrived, my husband had finished and the veg I had put on my plate, was now gone and no sign of any more. The steak was very good, but I had gone out to eat with my husband, not alone. For 2 steaks, 1plate of veg, 1 vodka/coke, 1 beer and a half bottle of red wine it came to €98 euros. Personally for that money I want great money and great food. It was probably worth €50. On the basis of value for money, I just didn't see it.

I shared the oxtail with my sister and it was very good, except that I wish it came with vegetables - it just came with sauce - that was it. After that, we ordered the specialty of the house - apple tart for dessert and it was served with ice cream. Then when the coffee came, they gave us the almond cookie - which was very delicate and hot from the oven. Overall, the bill came to much more than we budgeted but it was well worth it. The only caveat is that you need to ensure you clearly understand the portions you order because if you are sharing one order - they add a half portion more as it wouldn't be enough (this was the oxtail) for two. Will go back

review_preview: Dantxari is in the Calle Ventura Rodriguez (Metro station here) just north of the Plaza de España. As the name suggests, it serves traditional Basque food, and Basque food is allegedly the best cui-sine in Spain. Being located in a quiet street away from the...
review_full: Dantxari is in the Calle Ventura Rodriguez (Metro station here) just north of the Plaza de España. As the name suggests, it serves traditional Basque food, and Basque food is allegedly the best cui-sine in Spain. Being located in a quiet street away from the usual tourist areas the clientele when we went was, with the exception of my wife and I, entirely Spanish. The ambience is traditional, rustic, Basque Spanish, wooden beams, oak chairs, gingham tablecloths. We would never have found this restaurant by ourselves. It was recommended to us by Spanish colleagues. We arrived at 21.15. We immediately felt rather foolish at having arrived at such an outlandishly early time….for Madrid. Apart from us there was just one table of 10 celebrating someone’s birth-day. However, by 10.30 the place was buzzing and by 11.00 there wasn’t a table free. The menu was very impressive and featured: soups, fish, meat and stews. We know the menu offered authentic dishes when we saw lamb sweetbreads with mushrooms, braised Iberian pork cheeks and boneless pork trotters. I went for fish and shellfish soup followed by lomo de ciervo con salsa de grosellas (venison in redcurrant sauce). My wife went for jamón de belota (cured ham from free range acorn fed pigs) followed by merluza (hake). We skipped desert but had coffee and very good Spanish brandy. The bill, including a bottle of excellent rioja, came to around €110. The service was excellent – it always is in Spain. I think there is an English menu for non-Spanish speakers.

review_full: I was really looking for Bayres Beef, based on TA reviews. On our walks, we saw it is a small place, much morre like a fast food place (paper trays etc), but who cares? If you prepare to go to a Michelin star restaurant, don't go to Bayres Beef. But for good steak, it is your place. We went there for lunch (in the afternoon), and ordered two types of steak. Both served with wonderful chimichurri sauce. Bit spicy, but fresh by the lemon taste, was great with the beef. You can check the prices on their website (12-18 EURs), yes, for a good beef in Spain, you have to pay something like that. Argentinian red wine was nice next to the steaks.  The owner came to ask if everything is OK, are we satisfied, so he tries to take care of things. Technical info: inside there are just a few seats, so as a group, you can't sit together. Outside they have few 4 person tables.  We liked this place!

title_review: Great quality and price in the centre of Madrid
review_preview: We went for dinner recently and ordered bife (steak), solomillo (sirloin steak) and chorizo. The bife, we didn't really care for. It was not like in the pictures, but small, thin pieces of meat instead. Will probably not try that one again.The chorizo was...
review_full: We went for dinner recently and ordered bife (steak), solomillo (sirloin steak) and chorizo. The bife, we didn't really care for. It was not like in the pictures, but small, thin pieces of meat instead. Will probably not try that one again. The chorizo was very good, but nothing out of the ordinary. The solomillo, however, was spectacular. We ordered ours blue, and it was cooked to perfection, very juicy and red inside. We'll definitely come back for more. All dishes were accompanied by one cherry tomato and a small ball of mozzarella cheese. We were not sure what to do with ours, so we just eat them. They were acceptable. The wine was also nothing to kill for, but acceptable for the price. We ordered the rest of our bife and chorizo to take away, but they didn't include one of the bife pieces not the chorizo in the small tinfoil package they gave us. A bag was not provided. Other than that, service was adequate and fast. The manager, who's Argentinian, asked us how was the meal at the end, so that was a nice touch. This may sound a bit negative, but a total of 22 euros for two people and the spectacular solomillo means we'll definitely be back again.

review_preview: This restaurant was literally a couple of minutes walk from our hotel which after a long day's sightseeing made it an attractive option - besides, the reviews on Trip Advisor looked good so we decided we'd give it a go.   We hadn't booked but it...
review_full: This restaurant was literally a couple of minutes walk from our hotel which after a long day's sightseeing made it an attractive option - besides, the reviews on Trip Advisor looked good so we decided we'd give it a go. We hadn't booked but it was no problem - presumably because it was far too early in the evening for locals (you'd be unlikely to see locals out for dinner in Madrid before 9pm at the earliest). The restaurant is bigger than it first appears from outside & decor is attractive. Staff were friendly & we opted for our waiter's recommendation of turbot shared for two which I believe was the day's special rather than a standard menu item. It took a while to arrive but thats in no way a criticsm. If I want fast food I'll go to an appropriate place - in a restaurant I hope to get a meal cooked with a bit of loving care in whatever time it takes & that's exactly what we got here. Our fish was really good & so was the accompanying wine (house as far as I remember). Can't remember if we had dessert (rare for us) but after our meal they gave us a (free) liqueur each. All in all a very good meal served by friendly staff in pleasant surroundings & not at all expensive either. If you're staying as were, just around the corner at Sercotel Suites Viena, I'd say this place is a must but even if you're staying elsewhere it's still well located - only around 5 minutes walk from Plaza de Espana metro station. Recommended!

review_preview: A friend had previously recommended this place for "the best beef in Madrid" so we went there with high expectations. The place itself was pretty small. We were greeted by an elderly man who offered us the choice to either sit at the bar or...
review_full: A friend had previously recommended this place for "the best beef in Madrid" so we went there with high expectations.  The place itself was pretty small. We were greeted by an elderly man who offered us the choice to either sit at the bar or at a table outside. It was November (and seriously cold) so I balked a little at staying outside, but the man assured us that the terrace heaters were on full blast and so we eventually sat on the terrace. I melted completely when the man came out, a few minutes later, and offered me a blanket to keep warm. That was the sweetest thing I could imagine.  Our waitress was really friendly and cheery and she explained to us that they're an "eco" restaurant, namely that they use sugar cane plates with bamboo sticks for cutlery and that everything is recycled. I'm a bit ignorant as to why this is more eco-friendly than reusable ceramic plates but I appreciated their preoccupation with staying green. She further helped me choose a steak that wouldn't hurt my teeth, since neither I nor my boyfriend knew the difference between the multiple types of meat on the menu. She also suggested some stuffed baked potatoes which we only said yes to because she was so nice - but we didn't regret it cause they were delicious.  The food was stellar, the meat was really tender and delicious, although the portions were a bit on the small side, especially if you're a rabid meat eater. I was full but my boyfriend was left feeling a bit peckish.  Our cheery waitress also offered us a couple of shots on the house before we left. I don't know if we did something special to deserve them or if they do this with all their customers, but I was fair impressed.  All in all, tasty food and the kind of service that makes you want to come back for more. I fully recommend it.

THe menus were full of drink spillings, the tables and chairs full of fat. I went to this place beacuse I wanted meat and beacuse of it ratings and promises of low prices. The meat was good, and so was the olive oil marinade. I got one plate for 18.5 euro, which is the same rate as at a main course in 3-4 star restaurant in Madrid. The plate was made of paper. It was not a restaurant, it was a very run down street grill, which luckily had good meat. Another sunny side of the story is that one of the waiters was very forthcoming and attentive. Its definitely a place to go for people who don`t care about hygiene and just want a small bite. They had some options for 10 euro, small paper plates, si I guess that`s fair enough.

We arrived to have staff on hand to park the car for us (parking is tight on this street), and we were ushered in to our table in the back of the restaurant. The service was exceptional, and we had 2 or 3 people waiting on our table of 6. Food was presented in a most professional manner, with each course served on new plates and utensils. The wine selections were very good as well. All of the dishes we were served (at least 8) were exceptional in flavor, and presentation. The staff was professional in appearance and behavior, and they indeed treated us as guests. As for dress code, it was clear that all sorts of dress were worn by various patrons, but I felt most comfortable with a business casual/formal apparel, because it suited the ambiance of the establishment. If in the area, I highly recommend this hidden jewel of a restaurant.

I wish we had more time and some local friends to better enjoy our time at Dantxari.

review_preview: We had a full-dinner at La monteria, not tapas only. It started with a perfect amuse bouche - a plate of fried sardines, cod, and squid. Everything was fried so perfectly that we ordered an extra started (calamari fried in olive oil - very good...
review_full: We had a full-dinner at La monteria, not tapas only. It started with a perfect amuse bouche - a plate of fried sardines, cod, and squid. Everything was fried so perfectly that we ordered an extra started (calamari fried in olive oil - very good but not as the first plate). Porcini mushrooms with eggs and truffles were good; the portion perhaps even too large for a starter. Fried fish was as good as the one we started with. For the mains, we had oxtail (perfect), the Spanish version of risotto was juicy and tasty, and the tuna was fresh and of top quality. There was room for only one dessert (La monteria serves a variety of fantastic home-made sourdough breads which were simply too good not to eat throughout the dinner) and this was the dish I liked most: a cheese-based light cream, topped with a PX (sweet sherry) sauce and crumble, finished with grated parmesan (!). Very subtle, delicious, and innovative. For four people, the bill came to 170 EUR (including one bottle of wine). I will definitely return to try the tapas as well!

title_review: Tiny but perfect, near Retiro Park
review_preview: Made a lunch reservation here on a whim, and was so glad we did. We turned up 20 mins early because our 2 year old was tired from running around in El Retiro. We were greeted warmly and given a table straight away in the...
review_full: Made a lunch reservation here on a whim, and was so glad we did. We turned up 20 mins early because our 2 year old was tired from running around in El Retiro. We were greeted warmly and given a table straight away in the very small but fantastic dining room behind the main bar. The set up was quite formal, but everyone was very laid back - did not even bat an eyelid at my toddler. The very friendly waiter brought us a menu with English translation when it was obvious our Spanish was not up to par! The food was among the best we had in Madrid - we tried the red tuna (amazing!), mushrooms and truffled eggs (great combo) and ox tail (melt in the mouth). They were very helpful in that they served each dish up on two plates for me and my husband, so you don't have to fight over one plate! They were also kind enough to whip something up for our child, which she polished off in no time flat. We also shared a bottle of red and a dessert. Price-wise, we spent about Eu90 and felt it was value for money because of the amazing food - quality and quantity - and above all the service. Will definitely come back to try out more dishes next time we're in Madrid!

title_review: Top tip for your tapas trail

review_full: A proper, modern tapas bar and a very good restaurant serving high quality food and drink. (The red tuna is notably lush.) Service is fast and efficient. Everybody else - elbows out and enjoy.

Cannot recommend this place enough. Actually writing it from the gaff which I've Never done before. If you're deciding between places on where to go tonight - GO HERE X

title_review: lovely meal but a bit pricey
review_preview: there is much to like here:  a refined setting, a menu that reflects Basque traditions, attentive service.  BUT in a town with several strong options for this cuisine, I think it's a bit over priced.we shared two entrees:  the bacalao pil pil, and the...
review_full: there is much to like here: a refined setting, a menu that reflects Basque traditions, attentive service. BUT in a town with several strong options for this cuisine, I think it's a bit over priced. we shared two entrees: the bacalao pil pil, and the oxtails ... both were nicely prepared, the fish moist as can be and the oxtails cooked to the point falling from the bone without actually having done so .... as seems to be the norm here in Madrid, I'd have wished for a bit less salt ...  menu offers broad variety of seafoods (special fishes of the day included sea bream, turbot and tuna) , and meat from beef to lamb to pork ... all dishes are a la carte, so if you want a vegetable, order it! decent enough house wine, and a restaurant in which one can have a conversation without fighting the noise in other places. a great place for a family meal (there were several going on while we were there)

title_review: Great service, Steaks below average, expected more!
review_preview: I had some of the best steaks I've ever had in cancha dos in sotogrande Spain, which were Argentinian beef also, so the thought of bayres excited me. Sadly though, the beef was mediocre, too thin and unsatisfying. I didn't mind that food was served...
review_full: I had some of the best steaks I've ever had in cancha dos in sotogrande Spain, which were Argentinian beef also, so the thought of bayres excited me.  Sadly though, the beef was mediocre, too thin and unsatisfying. I didn't mind that food was served in paper plates and plastic utensils, because the prices were reasonable and it's hard to demand too much.  The more upsetting feature of my dining experience would be the continuous mist being run during dinner at the outside seating area. Yes the Spanish summer is hot, but how hygienic it is to my exposed food is also questionable. I appreciate the intentions management had though. Overall, I must still praise and give credit the the waitress/ staff of Bayres. She was excellent, articulate and helpful. I just wish the food was as good as she was.

Unlike the usual rowdy tapas places, this has a nice modern concept. Tried the fillet steak tapas that comes with 2 15X5 cm pieces, then sliced to 1cm thick pieces. Comes with farm bread and 2 sticks of cherry tomatoes with mozzarella cheese ball. The stick in medium rare was excellent! Well grilled which kept the moist in and taste great!  Ordered the agulla salad as well and a cola. Total bill came to €18.50. The menu is bilingual, staff speaks minimum English but friendly and approachable.

review_preview: Eating here was one of the highlights of our visit to Madrid. We visited for dinner 3 times which may not be very adventurous but why change a good thing ?.Arrived the first night without reservation but they managed to fit us in after...
review_full: Eating here was one of the highlights of our visit to Madrid. We visited for dinner 3 times which may not be very adventurous but why change a good thing ?. Arrived the first night without reservation but they managed to fit us in after 1/2 hour wait at the bar. After that I realised it was best to book.  This is a busy establishment but service was 'at our pace' and the staff always seemed to find the time for some fun and language lessons. Menus in English if required so ordering was not a problem in any way.We alternated between fillet (solomillo) and 1/2 chicken (pollo) with lemon. The steak was really excellent, my order of 'well done' coming out just about 'medium to rare' in UK terms which is the way I like it. A mushroom and ? whatever sauce accompanied the fillet and that was also first class.  The 1/2 chicken with lemon had probably never even sniffed a lemon but was undoubtedly the juiciest, tastiest, chicken we have ever eaten. Both pollo and the solomillo were accompanied by patatas provenzal which was very tasty. Plenty of garlic on the patatas which I do not usually like but it just seemed to fit the rest of the plate. Overall this place rates a 'Magnifico' in my book and is well worth a visit, or two.

title_review: Nice Argentinian beef in a cute little pedestrian street
review_preview: I'm torn between 3 & 4 stars - 3.5 would probably be right but I'll give them the 4 for the combination of the great beef and the value.3 minutes from Plaza de Santa Ana towards del Sol on a cute pedestrian street filled...
review_full: I'm torn between 3 & 4 stars - 3.5 would probably be right but I'll give them the 4 for the combination of the great beef and the value. 3 minutes from Plaza de Santa Ana towards del Sol on a cute pedestrian street filled with small tapas restaurants. Strangely, this place was pretty quiet that evening - other places had more traffic. I choose an Empanada as the appetizer and the sliced filet along with wine by the glass. The server spoke ok English but was a little off-putting in his manner, but the service was fine. I snagged a table outside. They had little heaters to take the chill off which was nice since it was the end of October. The empanada was fine although not exciting (I picked a traditional hummus based Empanada so it was probably intentionally a bit bland). The beef was quite good - an excellent cut of beef cooked to just right. Other people already commented on the plastic utensils. They worked fine though.  Don't waste time on dessert - it is just stuff they picked up somewhere and wasn't the least bit interesting. The wine wasn't bad and the price was good - 2- 3.50 Euro/glass. They had both Argentinian and Spanish wine. While I enjoyed it and would definitely go back to this area to eat, I don't know if I found this place exciting enough to repeat given the plethora of cute little tapas places downtown Madrid. But definitely worth visiting once if you like great beef.

review_preview: Walking around in Madrid all day (what a fun thing to do!!), it's coming to early evening, you're kind of tired, you're kind of eager to find a place for dinner. So what do you do? You walk around, see places, see where the most...
review_full: Walking around in Madrid all day (what a fun thing to do!!), it's coming to early evening, you're kind of tired, you're kind of eager to find a place for dinner. So what do you do? You walk around, see places, see where the most people are, you do not want to go to those touristic places on Plaza Mayor, you want something more of what the locals would prefer. So you find yourself walking up and down those little alleys, full of people, full of restaurants, full of buzz and you're wondering what this "Argentina en tapas" place might be. Do you pass by and walk away or do you sit yourself down and give it a try?? Well, if you have the time+ability to look it up on tripadvisor, you're in luck. Cause then you'll make an easy decision: Sit down and enjoy! This is a very cozy little place, best visited in summer (I would think it's too small inside), there's tables sitting people both at the front and back of the place - suggest the backside alley, it's much better and more relaxed. The food is (of course) meat, and it's superb. We had the "Duo", which is an assortment of all kinds of meats served there, so we tried it all. There's nothing that was less than excellent, perfectly cooked, "medio" at the suggestion of Marcello, our super-friendly waiter - cook - bar tender. We also got the baked potato with melted cheese plus a salad, both very good. In terms of quantity, two 45 year-olds were super-satisfied. Perhaps a couple of 205 year-olds may have wanted a tad more food. The serving comes in funny looking paper plates, I guess there's some room for improvement there, however the food is so delicious you don't care about the plates after a minute or two. The sangria was delicious as well, and at the end we could not help accepting a couple of liquor shots, a treat offered to us by Marcello. As soon as we had them, he brought out the whole bottle, for us to have as many as we wanted! But after more than a liter of sangria we were ok. All this for some 36 euros. Most definitely recommended for meat lovers, there's no way anyone would regret this.

title_review: If you like steak....find this place
review_preview: After reading the reviews we decided that we would definitely seek this place out.  We had fillet steak and sirloin steak with a potato Bayres as a side.  Steak was tender and as well cooked as I have ever had at a Gaucho Restaurant (and...
review_full: After reading the reviews we decided that we would definitely seek this place out. We had fillet steak and sirloin steak with a potato Bayres as a side. Steak was tender and as well cooked as I have ever had at a Gaucho Restaurant (and a fraction of the price) - my overly fussy 11 year old daughter said it was the best she had tasted......thank god!! A bottle of Malbec to wash it down, the very attentive Marcello looking after us and free Wi-Fi - everything you could want of a meal. With soft drinks and a sweet (for the above mentioned fussy daughter) we still had change from 50 euros - extremely good value. Can't recommend highly enough.

title_review: We liked our meal so much we kept coming back.
review_preview: Finding a decent meal in a foreign country can be a daunting experience. We ate here 3 times during our 6 day stay in Madrid. That is because our first culinary experience there was satisfying.We bought the 12.50 euro special each time. With that...
review_full: Finding a decent meal in a foreign country can be a daunting experience. We ate here 3 times during our 6 day stay in Madrid. That is because our first culinary experience there was satisfying. We bought the 12.50 euro special each time. With that came a choice of 3 appetizers, choice of 3 vegetable dishes, choice of 3 meat items (cooked over a woodflame), choice of 3 desserts and a choice of 3 beverages. Our food was seasoned and cooked well. It was plentiful and satisfying.  A down side for some may be that one needs to mention the "special meal" as they give you the menu with more expensive prices. It seems as though one needs to sit in the bar to get that special meal. We found the experience to be very pleasant. The other patrons of the restuarant seemed to include locals as well as tourists. The staff was helpful and gave us the "English" menu to help us pick out our dining choices. All in all, I would highly recommend this restuarant for weary/hungry travelors.

review_preview: It was our third evening in Madrid and had been very satisfied eating at the buffett restaurants on the previous evenings.  We were attracted to this restaurant by the clearly advertised sign in the window offering a steak dinner for 9.95 euros.On being seated...
review_full: It was our third evening in Madrid and had been very satisfied eating at the buffett restaurants on the previous evenings. We were attracted to this restaurant by the clearly advertised sign in the window offering a steak dinner for 9.95 euros. On being seated we were all given a complimentary glass of cava, which we thought was very nice. We were given the al la carte menue which was very expensive, we asked about the offer but were told it was not available at the weekend. We would have left but felt obliged to stay as we had accepted the free drink. We ordered from the menue and realised that the prices quoted did not include potatoes or veg,so making it even more expensive. The waitress seemed intent on us ordering drinks, we were asked three times, although we were still drinking the free cava, eventually we ordered water fro the table. I think the waitress may have been on commission and didn't think we were spending enough money as she was very rude to us all night, tutting and such like, reaching across people when they were eating and generally miserable.  The bill came to 100 euros including a cover charge of 2.20 Euro each for the bread and then a 10% service chare added. We paid the bill in full then asked to speak to the manager who didn't speak English, one of the other waitreses translate (she was very pleasant). He didn't seem bothered. On the whole i think you have to be spending a lot of money in this restaurant to get a half decent service.

review_preview: After finishing the 770 KM Camino de Santiago, we celebrated in Madrid's Bayres Beef Restaurant.   Of the hundreds of small restaurants in Madrid, we found one of the best.  It is also very close to Puerta del Sol, so visitors can find it easily.Jorge,...
review_full: After finishing the 770 KM Camino de Santiago, we celebrated in Madrid's Bayres Beef Restaurant. Of the hundreds of small restaurants in Madrid, we found one of the best. It is also very close to Puerta del Sol, so visitors can find it easily. Jorge, the owner imports only the best Argentine beef, His crew carefully grills this to order, resulting in succulent cuts done to perfection. They are prepared one at a time, so lose your hurry up attitude and enjoy a vaso de Malbec - it will be worth the wait. Jorge makes a bold statement of sustainability with his table: your dinner will be served on biodegradable paper plates and the cutlery will be recylable organic plastics. This in no way diminishes the quality of food, but adds a socially responsible theme to the eatery.  Jorge has selected a brief wine list that includes superb Malbecs from Argentina. Try them, you will not be disappointed. They are fruity, and toothsome and stand up well to the beef. After two months in country, I can honestly say this is the best meat I tasted in Spain. Special thanks to Jorge and his crew for making this evening memorable.

title_review: Delicious steak but rather strange dining experience!
review_preview: We went here as TA reviews were good. The restaurant is tiny & we ended up sitting in the narrow back street not in the tiny front square.  Our waiter spoke very little English & we all chose fillet steak, salad & baked potatoes. We...
review_full: We went here as TA reviews were good. The restaurant is tiny & we ended up sitting in the narrow back street not in the tiny front square. Our waiter spoke very little English & we all chose fillet steak, salad & baked potatoes. We were almost, but not quite, speechless when paper plates were placed in front of us with plastic cutlery & salad dressing in little sachets - did they have a dish washing problem? Should we move? We decided to pick up our jaws & sit tight & our steaks arrived. They were delicious & the baked potatoes with cheese absolutely wonderful too.  I have never eaten in a restaurant from paper plates & using plastic cutlery but if you can get your head round this it's fantastic food, very nice wine & amazingly cheap!! We did wonder what happens in winter though as the restaurant appears to be incredibly small inside. We all very much enjoyed our meal - and I am not a great steak eater!!

review_preview: Whenever in Madrid my wife and I visit this restaurant which we've known for more than 10 years.More than once, we come directly from the airport with our luggage !The staff is outstanding. Most of them have been with the restaurant forever... which...
review_full: Whenever in Madrid my wife and I visit this restaurant which we've known for more than 10 years. More than once, we come directly from the airport with our luggage ! The staff is outstanding. Most of them have been with the restaurant forever... which is always a good sign. The maitres are extremely professional, having all learnt their office from the most prestigious tables in Madrid. The local is relatively small but welcoming and cozy. They just underwent a decoration overhaul which is charming and gives more light to the place. The food is close to what you could find in the best restaurants in San Sebastian or Bilbao. Not in vain has the basque cuisine be renowned for ages. The prime material are superb and the cuisine itself is exquisite and inventive without being over the top. Among the gems: the lasagna of Xanguro ( fresh crab), the Funghi Porcini with foie gras ( in season), the tournedos 'Dantxari", steam cooked with a dash of olive oil, the Anglerfish ( rape) cooked with green garlic. The desserts are commendable, eg a fig pudding you will not find else where. The wine list is very well selected, flawless and affordable. All in all a highly recommended place next to Plaza de Espana. Reserve please.

Complimentary spiced pumpkin soup is provided along with crisp bread and soft cheese before your steak arrives. They serve very decent house wine at only 3 euros a glass - Nice. All in all a great place for a very civilised dining experience.

My recommendation would be to start with a fabulous empanada, then for a main, the solomillo steak (sirloin) together with ensalada rucola (rocket salad). To drink, the Malbec wine (postales del fin del mundo) is exquisite or go for a bottle of Quilmes (authentic Argentinian beer). The staff are friendly and attentive, so you can't really go wrong if you choose to eat in this restaurant.

review_preview: We dined at La Parilla de Maria last Sunday, March 17.  We discovered the restaurant quite by accident.  We had just returned from a trip to Toledo, were hungry and hadn't made dinner plans.  We were staying across the street at the Hotel Preciados and...
review_full: We dined at La Parilla de Maria last Sunday, March 17. We discovered the restaurant quite by accident. We had just returned from a trip to Toledo, were hungry and hadn't made dinner plans. We were staying across the street at the Hotel Preciados and decided to look "in our neighborhood.  The place was crowded, which is usually a good sign, and we had to wait for a table, but the sangria and the green and black olives made the wait quite acceptable. We got a decent table and were soon able to choose our meal and our wine.  I have to say, the steak I enjoyed at La Parilla was amazing. It was suggested by our waiter and I am most grateful for the suggestion. It was cooked perfectly to my liking and the quality of the meat and the seasoning was superb. Our service was quite adequate for such a busy night. The wine, which name I now forget, was excellent.  The price for this wonderful meal was very acceptable! I believe this may have been the best meal we had during our weeklong stay in Madrid.

title_review: The best Rib Eye i have ever had
review_preview: Dined here last Sunday evening, greeted with a very acceptable glass of Cava Rosado and some lovely cream cheese tapas. The atmosphere was very nice and the smell of burning coal on the grill wet the appetite. I had the best Rib Eye i have...
review_full: Dined here last Sunday evening, greeted with a very acceptable glass of Cava Rosado and some lovely cream cheese tapas. The atmosphere was very nice and the smell of burning coal on the grill wet the appetite. I had the best Rib Eye i have ever had in my life, the knife resembling a offensive weapon was not needed as it simply glided through the Beef. A good side of chips and a decent few bottles of Tempranillo. Everyone in the party commented on the quality of their meals, which included a Chateau Briand type style cut, Iberico Chuleta and succulent Chicken. A complementary Mango Sorbet also went down well! The service was friendly and efficient, simply cannot fault this establishment!

title_review: Mmmmm.....I can't stop thinking about the Steak!
review_preview: We've just came back from Madrid and came here Saturday for lunch. It was around 2pm and was empty at the time, so we got a seat outside in the sunshine. Absolute bliss!!We ordered a couple of smalls beers to start with and having...
review_full: We've just came back from Madrid and came here Saturday for lunch. It was around 2pm and was empty at the time, so we got a seat outside in the sunshine. Absolute bliss!! We ordered a couple of smalls beers to start with and having already done my research on Tripadvisor (I love you guys!) knew that we were going to have the Duo to share, rare. It was absolute perfection. All 3 cuts of steak was mouth-watering, you could tell that the bread was freshly baked as it was crunchy and soft and the Chimichurri was so good!! I could've had the duo all to myself it was that good!!! The bill came to 37 Euros, which included 3 beers, 1 red wine, water & the gorgeous Duo steak. Amazing value for great quality. We were even given liquors after our meal. I just wish I could've eaten here again on my trip! We tried to on Monday but unfortunately it didn't open until our flight was departing! :(

title_review: Mediocre Food Despite Hugh TripAdvisor Ranking
review_preview: We were in search of a Basque restaurant and followed the lead of other TripAdvisor reviewers who had ranked Dantxari as #77 out of 1,621 restaurants in Madrid. Were we disappointed. Although the appetizer of hot anchovies cooked in garlic, pepper, and oil was quite...
review_full: We were in search of a Basque restaurant and followed the lead of other TripAdvisor reviewers who had ranked Dantxari as #77 out of 1,621 restaurants in Madrid. Were we disappointed. Although the appetizer of hot anchovies cooked in garlic, pepper, and oil was quite tasty, the two main courses were big disappointments. -- txangurro a la donostierra was thin, too uniform in texture and color, and oversalted; the fried hake (merluza) stuffed with crab was flavorless, blandly presented, and insufficiently firm. There are many many better restaurants in Madrid. I have great memories of eating txangurro --- and I will try not to let this one bad experience drown them out.

review_preview: I liked everything about the restaurant! Ambience like home, cosy, could be for a relaxed lunch/dinner family or friends. On the first floor it looks more casual, on the second slightly more formal, could be also for a date!The food is very good, delicious!...
review_full: I liked everything about the restaurant! Ambience like home, cosy, could be for a relaxed lunch/dinner family or friends. On the first floor it looks more casual, on the second slightly more formal, could be also for a date! The food is very good, delicious! The service is excellent! There are mostly waiters of slightly older generation, feels like they have been there for ages and truly care for the service they provide. The only reason I am putting 4 and not five is because I think it is a little expensive for the portions it offers. I had a seafood soup 1/2 portion, a crab stew 1/2 portion and venison 1/2 portion, dessert and wine and paid about 55 euros! I think for half portions they costed too much for the quantity they put on the plate. Especially the venison was tiny little two pieces! Well the full dish was 4 tiny little pieces and costed over 20euros. I don't think it would be enough to make you feel happy and not hungry. But anyway, if money is not object, I certainly recommend!

review_preview: I took my girlfriend to see the Temple of Debod in Madrid for Valentines day and ended up at Dantxari because it was a very short walk away. I am a student, so I wanted to impress her with a posh meal out but I...
review_full: I took my girlfriend to see the Temple of Debod in Madrid for Valentines day and ended up at Dantxari because it was a very short walk away. I am a student, so I wanted to impress her with a posh meal out but I couldn't afford to spend much money. Not only did we get a taste of traditional Northern Spanish food (not the touristy tapas you get everywhere else), but the service was exceptional. We got 3 half rations to share and although the choice of dishes and the size of the servings wasn't the best, the quality was undeniably brilliant. The Bacalao was perhaps the best dish, just in terms of taste, that I have ever had. The staff were friendly and were patient with my Spanish, allowing me to practice without patronising me in any way. At the end of the meal we were given a huge fortune cookie (literally huge) and 2 shots of beautiful flavored liquors on the house. In all, a romantic, posh meal out with great service and even better food only set me back 45 euros.

Even though this restaurant is on the smaller side the decor makes you feel very comfortable, and in addition the service was spotless. title_review: Amazing food. Amazing atmosphere. Amazing find.
review_preview: To be honest we stumbled on this little gem by accident. But we are glad we did. This place is wonderful. First, the atmosphere and decor were simple, but friendly and warm. Secondly the staff were very helpful and patient (especially to those who speak...
review_full: To be honest we stumbled on this little gem by accident. But we are glad we did. This place is wonderful. First, the atmosphere and decor were simple, but friendly and warm. Secondly the staff were very helpful and patient (especially to those who speak very little and bad Spanish). Finally, the food. Oh my god the food! Neither of us are vegans by any measure but having had a lot of tapas on this trip it was really nice to have some well-cooked vegetables, not fried in loads of oil and dripping with ham or chorizo. We tried the mushroom croquettes, the potatoes with a vega sauce and the grilled vegetables and it was all incredible. We didn't try any of the desserts but again they looked amazing. I would really recommend this place to anyone not just vegans.

review_preview: We had made a reservation for 20:00 after they had suggested 22:00 (we thought they were joking, but we soon learned that everyone in Spain eats at 22:00...) so we were alone in the restaurant. This turned out to a great opportunity to talk with...
review_full: We had made a reservation for 20:00 after they had suggested 22:00 (we thought they were joking, but we soon learned that everyone in Spain eats at 22:00...) so we were alone in the restaurant. This turned out to a great opportunity to talk with the owner/chef who recommended the menu based on what was in season and the freshest.  We thus started out with sangria (of course) and olives from Seville (wonderful!) followed with the chef's first proposed dish: simple tomatoes in oil and salt. I was surprised but really enjoyed the taste and sweetness of fresh tomatoes with just a dab of oil and salt! (Note: it's been a few years since we've seen the summer...) We then shared grilled green asparagus and broiled white asparagus. Both were delicious and both surprised us as how simple vegetables could be so enjoyable when cooked right with simply a dash of salt and oil. We then had sea bass - simply yet well prepared in that there were no special spices other than oil and salt but it was the cooking of the meat that made it just right: pan-fried fish that was juicy without any other taste than the taste of the sea bass itself. We then followed with tuna. Now, though the bass was simple and delicious, the tuna turned out to be exquisite! It was served with a bit of teriyaki sauce and cooked just right as you could still taste the tenderness of the local tuna with the seared exterior. We then finished dinner with a cheesecake and an apple tort. The cheesecake had a distinctive touch which I could not identify but it was delicious. My wife's apple tort was again very tasty. In summary, of the three restaurants we ate in Madrid, this was the most delicious we had and we recommend Garcia de Navarra.

title_review: Amazingly fairly priced wine list and great food
review_preview: My god what a dinner we had there !As a wine lover I am always fond of restaurants where you have a great wine list. I have been to many and this one truly ranks among the best. I wish I knew a place...
review_full: My god what a dinner we had there ! As a wine lover I am always fond of restaurants where you have a great wine list. I have been to many and this one truly ranks among the best. I wish I knew a place like this one in my home town of Paris. We did not order specific food but the waiter offered us some sort of tasting menu where they kept bringing us small portions of sophisticated and delicious meals (especially the almost raw tuna which was unbelievable).  The best part was obviously the wine list which offers high quality and rare wines at very very fair prices, often cheaper than what you would find at a nearby wine shop. They offer wines from all over the world, with a main focus on Spain and France. They also have some old vintages (30, 40, even 50 years old bottles). One of the best wine bar I have ever been !

Maybe we were just unlucky but felt slightly disappointed and wouldn't recommend it to others.
